This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (N=38) of a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss/Cyberball-type manipulation). The (toss – button press) high-frequency contrast indexes increased social interaction/social reward (affiliation) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (N=38) comparing a social interaction condition (ball toss) to a button-press control in a high-frequency social interaction condition. The task probes social interaction/social reward (social processing), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (toss – button press) from healthy adult participants in a virtual ball-toss social interaction task. The task measures social interaction/cooperation (non-facial social communication — reception of others' actions/social reward), and the analysis is not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (toss – button press; high-frequency social interaction) targets social reward/inclusion rather than an explicit Perception and Understanding of Self task. The contrast does not directly measure self-related judgments or self-knowledge (it indexes reward/enjoyment from increased social interaction), so it does not meet the annotation's requirement that the task/contrast assess perception/understanding of the self.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast from a healthy adult sample (n=38) comparing a social interaction condition (toss) to a control (button press) in a ball-toss game. The task probes social interaction/inclusion (perception of others' actions/behavior), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (e.g., cooperation/social interaction). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain univariate parametric contrast (conjunction of IP and OP regret conditions) from a study of healthy adults examining observation/understanding of another's regret — a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast probes cognitive/empathetic processing of regret in a gambling task (self vs observed regret), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain healthy-group analysis, the task and contrast do not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain parametric fMRI contrast in healthy adults probing the neural response to observing another person's regret (understanding others' emotional state). That addresses reception of socially relevant emotional information (social communication) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast probes first‑person and other‑person regret (a conjunction of experiencing and observing another's regret) and is focused on understanding others' emotions (a mirror/empathy question), not on processes of self‑perception/self‑knowledge. Although it likely uses group whole‑brain fMRI in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not target Perception and Understanding of Self as defined, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate parametric conjunction (IP vs IF and OP vs OF) from a healthy adult sample studying observation/understanding of others' regret/disappointment — a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis examines regret/disappointment in a gambling task (first‑person and observed regret), which targets cognitive/emotional processing of counterfactual outcomes rather than affiliation or attachment. Although it appears to be a group whole‑brain contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not measure affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, close‑relationship, cooperation/competition), so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate parametric conjunction identifying regions common to first-person (IP) and observed-other (OP) regret. The study used healthy adult participants and the OP condition directly measures the perception/understanding of another's emotional state (regret). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (conjunction of IP and OP conditions) from a healthy adult sample probing observation/understanding of others' regret (a social-processing task). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain group-level parametric fMRI contrast (self and other regret), the contrast indexes experience/observation of regret (empathy/mentalizing) rather than an exchange or reception/production of social communicative signals. The analysis does not clearly operationalize a Social Communication task/contrast (facial or non‑facial communication, social comparison/cooperation as defined), so it does not meet the "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain, univariate parametric conjunction analysis from a study of experiencing vs observing regret in healthy adults. The contrast includes an OP (observing/other) condition (conjunction of IP and OP), so it indexes perception/understanding of another's emotional state. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and thus meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

The contrast/tests probe regret/disappointment processing and the shared activation for experiencing and observing another's regret (conjunction of IP and OP). This addresses emotion resonance/social cognition about others rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although participants are healthy and the map is likely whole-brain, the analysis does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined, so it should be excluded.

This analysis probes regret (first‑person and observed regret) in a gambling task — a cognitive/empathic emotion contrast — not tasks or contrasts that measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close‑other vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole‑brain healthy group contrast, the psychological construct does not match the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain contrast in healthy adults comparing conditions involving observing/understanding another person's regret (a receptive social process). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, and the task measures a social communicative process (reception of socially relevant emotional information), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (Females > Males). Per the criteria, subgroup/sex between-group contrasts are excluded, so this analysis should not be included despite involving a social (regret/other-understanding) task.

This is a group-level, univariate whole-brain parametric conjunction (IP and OP) from a healthy adult sample examining regret elicited by observing another's choice (OP) alongside first-person regret (IP). It directly probes perception/understanding of others (observing others' regret), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, and thus meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the reported contrast is a conjunction of experienced- and observed-regret (IP and OP). The focus is on shared representation of regret for self and other (a mirror/empathy question), not specifically on processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or explicit perception/understanding of the self. Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (Females > Males), which violates the exclusion criterion disallowing subgroup vs subgroup contrasts. Additionally, the analysis targets regret processing rather than an affiliation/attachment task/contrast.

This is a between-group contrast (Females > Males for OP–OF), which falls under excluded subgroup/ between-group comparisons. In addition, the contrast indexes observation of others' regret (perception of others) rather than processes of self-perception/ self-knowledge.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (Males > Females). Although the task probes social processing (observing others' regret) and likely uses whole-brain fMRI, the inclusion criteria exclude subgroup/between-group contrasts, so this analysis should not be included.

This contrast is a between-group comparison (Females > Males), which falls under the exclusion criterion for between-group/subgroup contrasts. The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain map generalizable to the healthy adult population (i.e., within-group/main effect). Even though the task involves observing others' regret (social cognition), the between-sex contrast disqualifies it.

The reported contrast ("Females > Males" for OP−OF) is a between-group sex comparison (interaction), which falls under the exclusion criteria. Although the task probes understanding others' regret, between-group contrasts are excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females). The inclusion rules exclude between-group contrasts/interactions. Although the task involves observing others' regret (social cognition), the specific analysis is a group comparison and therefore should not be included.

This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females), which violates the exclusion criterion disallowing subgroup vs subgroup comparisons. In addition, the task probes regret (a cognitively-generated emotion) rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the task-domain inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Males > Females) for the OP−OF comparison, i.e. a subgroup vs subgroup effect. Per the exclusion criteria, between-group contrasts/interactions are not eligible even though the task targets perception/understanding of others.
This is a between-group (Males > Females) contrast. The inclusion rules exclude subgroup/between-group contrasts, so it should not be included despite being a whole-brain task analysis.

This is a between-group (Females > Males) contrast of a parametric regret analysis, not a task measuring affiliation/attachment. The contrast therefore violates the exclusion criterion against subgroup/between-group comparisons and does not index affiliation/attachment processes.

This is a between-group gender comparison (Females > Males), which meets the exclusion criterion for subgroup vs subgroup contrasts. Additionally the contrast is a parametric regret/gambling comparison rather than a task/contrast clearly measuring Social Communication per the annotation definition. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a direct between-group (Females > Males) contrast (subgroup vs subgroup). Although the task probes social processing (observing others' regret) and likely uses healthy adults and whole-brain analysis, between-group contrasts are excluded by the criteria.

This is a between-group (Females > Males) contrast (direct gender comparison) rather than a within-group whole-brain map generalizable to the healthy adult population. Between-group/subgroup contrasts are excluded by the criteria, so the analysis should not be included.

This is a between-group (Females > Males) contrast from a direct gender comparison, which matches the exclusion criterion for subgroup vs subgroup contrasts. In addition, the contrast concerns observing others' regret (OP condition) rather than processes of perceiving/understanding the self, so it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' task requirement.

This is a direct between-group contrast (Males > Females) comparing subgroups, which meets the exclusion criterion of subgroup/between-group contrasts even though the task is social (regret observation). Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a between-group (Males > Females) contrast (direct gender comparison), which meets the exclusion criterion disallowing subgroup vs subgroup / between-group contrasts. Even if the sample is healthy and the task involves social emotion, the contrast is not a within-group, generalizable whole-brain map.

This analysis is a direct between-group (Males > Females) comparison in the OP condition. The inclusion rules exclude between-group/subgroup contrasts or interactions; therefore it does not meet the whole-brain, within-group criteria for 'perception_others' despite involving observation of others' regret.

This analysis is a between-group (Males > Females) gender comparison of a parametric regret effect rather than a within-group, generalizable healthy-adult contrast of affiliation/attachment. The task probes regret/empathic resonance, not affiliation/attachment per the inclusion examples, and between-group contrasts are explicitly excluded.

This is a between-group (Males > Females) gender comparison and therefore excluded by the criterion disallowing subgroup vs subgroup contrasts. In addition, the contrast concerns observing others' regret (OP) rather than Perception/Understanding of the self, so it does not match the 'perception_self' construct.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Words > Faces) and the study focus on communicative/language processes (naming, requesting) rather than on affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast specifically measures affiliation and attachment.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level contrast from healthy adults, the contrast ("Words > Faces") and the study focus on language/communicative actions, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self and should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, random-effects contrast from healthy adults, the contrast ‘Words > Faces’ indexes basic stimulus-type processing (word vs face) rather than a social-communication task or contrast (e.g., communicative intent, social interaction, loved one vs stranger, request vs naming). It does not specifically measure social communication per the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level random effects contrast on healthy adults, the specific contrast (Words > Faces) does not specifically index social processing or a social-communication construct. The study overall investigates communicative actions, but this particular contrast contrasts language vs face stimuli and is not a social-processing contrast (e.g., Request vs Naming or other social-interaction conditions), so it does not meet the requirement that the analysis measure social processing.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects contrast (Request > Naming) in healthy adult participants probing understanding of speech acts/communication (social interaction). It is a within-group task-evoked univariate map measuring social communication, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast is Words > Faces (a low-level stimulus/category contrast) and does not index Perception or Understanding of Others (e.g., mental state inference, social interaction, animacy or action perception). Although the study examines communicative actions, this specific whole-brain contrast does not measure social cognition per the inclusion definition.

The contrast Request > Naming probes understanding of speech acts (requests) in a social interactive communicative context, which fits Social Communication. The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain random-effects univariate contrast in healthy adults (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain group analysis on healthy adults, the task contrasts speech-act types (Request vs Naming) probing communicative/action-related and language processes rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). It does not operationalize attachment/affiliation constructs, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (Request > Naming) indexes understanding of communicative actions/social interactive knowledge (processing others' speech acts), not processes of self‑perception, self‑awareness, agency, or self‑knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This is a whole-brain, group-level contrast (Request > Naming) in healthy adults that indexes understanding of communicative actions/social interaction (recognition of others' speech acts and action-related/social interactive knowledge). That fits the Perception & Understanding of Others construct (action/social intent perception) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

The contrast Request > Naming probes social communication (interpretation of utterances as speech acts), is a task-evoked, group-level univariate whole-brain contrast in a healthy adult sample, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. (Table caption inconsistency noted but the analysis name/description match the social-processing criteria.)

Although this is a whole-brain, healthy adult group contrast (Request > Naming), the task contrasts communicative speech acts (requesting vs naming) and does not measure affiliation or attachment (close relationships, bonding, kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger, etc.). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" annotation.

The contrast Request > Naming is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast in healthy adults probing comprehension of communicative actions (understanding utterances as Requests versus Naming). This directly reflects social communication (reception of non‑facial/verbal communicative information) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast Request > Naming probes understanding of others' communicative actions (interpreting speech acts), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. The report describes a whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate contrast in healthy adults (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from (presumably) healthy adults, the contrast reflects processing of communicative actions (Request vs Naming / Words vs Faces) and social/linguistic understanding, not processes of self-perception, self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criterion.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects contrast (Naming > Request) from a task manipulating speech acts (social communication). Participants appear to be healthy adults and the contrast probes social processing (understanding communicative actions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Naming > Request) probes different communicative speech acts, not affiliation/attachment or bonding (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it involves social communication, it does not measure attachment-related processes as defined by the inclusion criteria, so it should be excluded.

The contrast contrasts speech-act types (Naming vs Request / words vs faces) probing language and social communicative processing, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self per the annotation definition.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (random effects) within-subject contrast comparing communicative speech acts (Naming vs Request) in healthy adult participants. The task probes production/reception of communicative actions (speech acts), fitting the Social Communication construct (production of non‑facial communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The contrast is Mentalising > Factual memory (theory-of-mind), not a task or contrast probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding). Although it is a healthy-group whole-brain task contrast, it does not measure affiliation or attachment processes.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Mentalising > Factual memory) from a healthy adult fMRI sample (Experiment 2, n=17) assessing theory-of-mind/mentalising, which is a canonical social-processing construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from a healthy adult sample (random-effects fMRI contrast). The task explicitly manipulated interpretation of utterances as different communicative actions (Naming vs Request), which taps social/communicative intention processing (understanding others' actions/intentions). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes mentalising/theory-of-mind (inferring others' mental states) versus factual memory. The annotation target 'perception_self' requires tasks probing self-perception/self-knowledge (agency or self-knowledge), which this contrast does not assess, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (mentalising > factual memory), the contrast probes theory-of-mind/mentalising (social cognition) rather than social communication per the provided annotation definition. The task involves inferring beliefs from stories, not the exchange or reception/production of communicative signals, so it does not meet the 'social_communication' inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate comparison (Mentalising > Factual memory) from a healthy adult fMRI sample and targets understanding others' mental states (theory of mind/mentalising), matching the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (mentalising parametric > factual memory parametric) from a healthy adult fMRI sample assessing theory-of-mind/mentalising, which is a social processing construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes mentalising/theory-of-mind demands (mentalising > factual memory), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast on healthy adults, the task domain does not meet the affiliation/attachment inclusion criterion.

The contrast isolates mentalising (theory-of-mind/understanding others' intentions) versus factual memory. Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it targets understanding others rather than self-related perception/knowledge, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (mentalising > factual memory) from a healthy adult fMRI sample (Experiment 2, n=17). The contrast measures understanding of others' mental states (mentalising), which fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI contrast from an experiment on mentalising/higher-order intentionality (theory-of-mind), which is squarely a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are healthy adults and the result is reported as whole-brain significant activations (not ROI/ connectivity or between-group). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group fMRI analysis on healthy adults, the task contrasts assess higher-order mentalising/intention inference (theory-of-mind) versus factual memory rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/domain inclusion criterion for 'affiliation_attachment.'

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes mentalising/theory-of-mind versus factual memory. This probes inferencing about others' mental states (social cognition) rather than the exchange or production/reception of social communicative signals. It therefore does not meet the annotation's requirement for a Social Communication task/contrast and should be excluded.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain group contrast on healthy adults, it tests higher-order mentalising/theory-of-mind (reading stories and inferring intentions) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior (e.g., face/affect recognition, gaze/expressive reciprocity, cooperation/competition scenarios). The task measures mental state inference (social cognition) but does not operationalize Social Communication as defined, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task fMRI contrast from an experiment on mentalising/theory-of-mind in healthy adult participants (fMRI n=17). The task explicitly probes social cognition (mentalising/higher-order intentionality) and the reported results are whole-brain univariate activations, so it meets the inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked analysis from a healthy adult fMRI sample (Experiment 2 of the paper) reporting common activations for mentalising/factual-memory contrasts. The task explicitly probes theory-of-mind / understanding others' mental states, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This analysis tests mentalising (theory-of-mind / higher-order intentionality) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment. Although it uses a healthy adult sample and reports whole-brain group-level task contrasts, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation), so it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria.

This analysis probes mentalising/theory-of-mind (higher-order intentionality) from story reading, not an exchange of socially relevant information or communication (facial/non-facial production or reception). Although it is social cognition and meets sample and whole-brain criteria, it does not measure Social Communication as defined by the annotation, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adults, the contrast reflects higher-order intentionality/theory-of-mind (understanding others' mental states) rather than processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. The task compares mentalising/factual memory conditions (common areas in A and B), so it does not meet the requirement to measure Perception and Understanding of Self.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI analysis on healthy adults, the contrast/analysis ('Mentalising parametric') targets theory-of-mind/mentalising (understanding others' intentions) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. It therefore does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self domain.

The contrast is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI analysis of mentalising (a parametric modulation of higher-order intentionality) in healthy adult participants (fMRI N=17). This measures understanding of others' mental states (theory-of-mind), fitting the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This analysis is a parametric contrast of factual memory (non-social memory) from a theory-of-mind study, not a task or contrast measuring affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or kinship/cooperation scenarios). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not meet the domain requirement for Affiliation and Attachment.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI contrast from healthy adults, the analysis is a parametric modulation of factual memory (the non-social control condition). It does not index social processing or a social-related task (e.g., theory-of-mind/mentalising), so it fails the requirement that the contrast measure Social Processing.

The contrast is a 'factual memory parametric' effect (non-mentalising/factual memory) rather than a measure of perceiving or understanding others' mental states or social actions. Although it likely is a whole‑brain group map from healthy adults, it does not probe the Perception and Understanding of Others construct, so it should be excluded.

This contrast indexes parametric effects of factual memory (a non-social control) rather than a social-communication task/contrast. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, healthy-group analysis, it does not measure exchange or processing of socially relevant communicative information, so it fails the content requirement for 'social_communication.'

This contrast ('Factual memory parametric') indexes factual memory for story content, not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it appears to be a whole-brain group-level task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non‑partnered) from healthy adult participants performing a joint-action (social) task. It directly measures social processing (interaction/affiliation) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (partnered vs non-partnered movements). The contrast indexes interactive, nonverbal social exchange (coordinated, communicative physical contact), which falls under social communication (production/reception of non-facial communicative signals). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (partnered > non-partnered) that indexes brain activity during joint/interactive action with another person. It probes perception/action of others and social interaction (cooperative joint action), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — therefore it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

The contrast is a whole-brain, group-level voxelwise comparison (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult participants and indexes social/interactive behavior (joint/partnered action vs solo), which maps onto affiliation/cooperation-type tasks. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for affiliation_attachment.

This is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (partnered > solo/alone) probing joint action/cooperation which engages self-related processes (agency/self-orientation, self-monitoring, mentalizing). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis and maps onto the Perception/Understanding of Self construct (e.g., cooperation/social interaction implicating self/agency).

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants in a two-person joint-action paradigm (leader vs other conditions). The task probes social interaction/roles (leading, following, mutual) and thus measures social processing relevant to affiliation/interactive social cognition, and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants examining roles in improvised joint action (leading vs other conditions). The task indexes interpersonal, cooperative/tactile communication (production of non‑facial social signals via physical coupling), which fits the Social Communication construct (e.g., cooperation/production of non‑facial communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting‑state, or between‑group contrast.

Although this is a whole‑brain group contrast in healthy adult dancers, the contrast (Leading > Conjunction) indexes role-related motor/planning and self‑oriented processes in joint action rather than an affiliation/attachment manipulation. The task is joint improvisation/dance, and the specific contrast does not target affiliative bonds (e.g., partnered vs stranger/loved‑one, cooperation vs competition) so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (Partnered > Non-partnered: Leading+Following+Mutual > Solo+Alone) in healthy adult participants performing a social joint-action task. It directly measures social interaction/processing and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast from healthy adult participants in a joint-action task, the contrast 'Leading > …' indexes self-oriented motor planning/sequencing and action monitoring rather than perception or understanding of another person. The study description indicates Leading is associated with self-oriented motor processes (whereas Following shows externally-oriented/social-cognitive processing). Therefore this specific contrast does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

The contrast targets the role of Leading (vs other conditions) in healthy adult dancers and, per the paper, indexes self-orientation/agency and self-monitoring processes (motor planning, action monitoring). It is reported as whole-brain group-level activation peaks (Talairach coordinates, t-values) in a healthy sample, so it fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' (agency/self-monitoring) inclusion criteria.

The contrast (Partnered > Non-partnered: Leading + Following + Mutual > Solo + Alone) probes interpersonal joint action/cooperation (physical social interaction), which falls under Social Communication. The sample is healthy adult participants and the result is a group-level whole-brain univariate task-evoked contrast (voxelwise peaks), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes joint motor interaction (leading, following, mutual improvisation) and sensorimotor/social-cognitive processes of joint action rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation framed as bonding). The partnered versus solo contrast indexes partnered action, not attachment or relationship processes per se, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment task criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast reflects role-related sensorimotor/social processing for 'following' in a joint-action task (externally-oriented somatosensation, motion tracking, outcome monitoring) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. It does not operationalize Perception and Understanding of Self (e.g., self vs other / self-judgment contrasts), so it should be excluded from the "perception_self" annotation.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task fMRI contrast from healthy adult participants examining the 'following' role in a joint-action task (perception/tracking of a partner’s movements). The contrast indexes perception/action understanding of another person (externally oriented/social-cognitive processes), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise contrast from healthy adult participants performing a joint-action (partnered) task. The mutual/partnered condition probes social interaction and mentalizing/social-reward processes (i.e., social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants (Talairach peak activations with FDR correction). The contrast indexes partnered/mutual joint action (symmetric, pre-learned interaction) and elicits mentalizing and social-reward areas, which aligns with affiliation/attachment (positive social bonding/cooperative interaction). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants comparing partnered (joint action: Leading/Following/Mutual) versus non-partnered (Solo/Alone) movement. The task measures interpersonal, cooperative joint action (social interaction/communication) and the contrast isolates social vs non-social conditions. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) from healthy adult participants engaging in interactive joint action (social task). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group clinical contrast, and directly indexes social processing (partnered interaction vs solo), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast isolates a social interaction condition (Mutual) that the authors report as engaging mentalizing/social-reward areas, so it indexes perception/understanding of others. The data are from a healthy adult sample and reported as whole-brain group-level voxelwise results (peak coordinates), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison. Therefore it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, within‑group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast reflects joint action/social interaction (partnered vs non‑partnered / mutual condition) and was reported to recruit mentalizing and social‑reward systems. It does not probe self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or explicit agency/self‑evaluation processes required for the “perception_self” construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (partnered > non‑partnered) that indexes social, cooperative/paired interaction (physical partnering vs solo), which maps onto affiliation/attachment-type processes (positive social interaction/cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate contrast (Partnered > Non-partnered) in healthy adult dancers comparing joint action with another person versus solo/alone. The contrast directly probes perception/processing of another agent during interaction (action/social perception), so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult dancers measuring joint/partnered action — a form of social interaction/communication (non-facial, cooperative coordination). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The contrast (partnered > non-partnered: Leading + Following + Mutual > Solo + Alone) tests presence of social/joint action vs solitary movement rather than processes specifically probing self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency judgments. Although the study discusses ‘self-orientation’ for the leading role, this contrast mixes roles (self- and other-oriented) and does not isolate perception/understanding of the self. The analysis is whole-brain on healthy adults, but it does not meet the annotation’s task/content requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

The contrast (partnered > non-partnered) is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast from healthy adult participants performing a social joint-action task (leading/following/mutual vs solo/alone). It indexes social interaction/processing (affiliation/interaction, perception of others), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) in healthy adult dancers that directly indexes dyadic joint action/interaction (physical coupling, coordination), which fits the Social Communication domain (non-facial production/reception, cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (partnered > non-partnered) from healthy adult participants performing a cooperative joint-action task. The contrast indexes social/partnered interaction (cooperation/physical coupling), which maps onto affiliation-related processes. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level comparison in healthy adults, it contrasts partnered versus non‑partnered movement (social coupling) rather than probing self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge). The contrast does not specifically measure perception/understanding of the self, so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion for "perception_self."

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (partnered > non-partnered) from healthy adult participants performing a joint-action/social interaction task. The contrast indexes social interaction/action perception (presence of a partner versus alone), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the Leading > Solo contrast indexes motor-planning/self-orientation in a joint-action/dance task rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close-relationship, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, or bonding scales). The task probes joint motor control/role dynamics, not affiliation/attachment per the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (leading vs solo movement). The contrast indexes self-oriented/agency-related processes (leading is described as 'self-orientation', involving motor planning and action monitoring), which falls under the Perception and Understanding of Self (agency) construct. It does not appear to be an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (Leading > Solo) from a sample of healthy adult dancers performing a joint-action task. The contrast compares an interpersonal role (leading) to a non-social solo condition, indexing social interaction/processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a within-subject, whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants comparing a cooperative joint-action role (Leading) to Solo movement. Leading in a physically coupled dyad indexes socially-directed, non‑facial communicative/coordination processes (cooperation/joint action), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast — so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although the study used social/interactive tasks with healthy adults and reports whole‑brain contrasts, the specific contrast 'Leading > Solo' indexes self‑oriented motor planning during partnered action rather than perception or understanding of others (e.g., action perception or mentalizing). The contrast does not target representations of others' states/traits/intentions, so it does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise (whole-brain) univariate analysis in healthy adult participants showing brain activations positively correlated with self-reported 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. Imitation is a social processing task (perception/response to others' actions), and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group contrast — thus it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis in healthy adults, the task and contrast index an urge to imitate meaningless actions (imitation drive), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria.

Although the sample and analysis are healthy, group-level, whole-brain task-evoked maps, the contrast indexes an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions rather than the exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. The task does not probe receptive/expressive social communication (facial or non‑facial) or communicative intent, so it does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample; group-level whole-brain voxelwise analysis reporting positive correlations between brain activation and participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal self-related state). The contrast measures a self‑referential/internal state (Perception/Understanding of Self), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

Healthy adult participants; group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis relating task-evoked activation to self-reported 'urge to imitate' (parametric correlation); task measures spontaneous imitation, a social-processing construct (social learning/communication). Not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) analysis in healthy adults showing brain activation correlated with subjects' urge to imitate observed actions. The task involves observing/imitating others' actions (fits the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

This analysis measures 'urge to imitate' for meaningless bimanual actions (imitation drive), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, bonding). Although conducted in healthy adults and likely a whole-brain within-group correlation, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activity with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' — an internal cognitive/emotional state (self-monitoring/awareness). It is not an ROI, between-group, or connectivity analysis, so it meets the perception_self inclusion criteria.

Although the sample and analysis appear to be whole-brain, the contrast indexes an urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions rather than exchange or processing of socially meaningful communicative signals. The task does not probe reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative content (e.g., gestures with social meaning, eye contact, social scenarios), so it does not meet the Social Communication construct.

The analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) functional connectivity analysis, which falls under seed-based/effective connectivity and is explicitly excluded by the criteria. Although the sample and task are appropriate (healthy adults, social/imitation task), PPI analyses do not meet the whole-brain univariate task-evoked map requirement.

Healthy adult, group-level whole-brain univariate analysis correlating brain activation with participants' urge to imitate observed actions. The task involves perceiving others' actions (Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others) and the analysis is not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast.

This is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity analysis (seed-based/effective connectivity), which is explicitly excluded. Additionally, the task probes urge to imitate (spontaneous imitation), not an affiliation/attachment task or contrast; it is not a whole‑brain univariate task activation meeting the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) seed-based connectivity/effective connectivity analysis, which is explicitly excluded by the criteria. In addition, it does not represent a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast probing Perception/Understanding of Self. Although the sample is healthy adults, the analysis type and target construct do not meet the inclusion requirements.

This analysis is a psychophysiological interaction (PPI) functional connectivity analysis. The inclusion criteria require a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) map; the exclusion criteria explicitly rule out seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI). Therefore it should not be included in the social_communication annotation.

This is a PPI (psychophysiological interaction) connectivity analysis (table caption: "Results of the PPI analysis"). The inclusion criteria require group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrasts; seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI) are explicitly excluded, so this analysis should not be included.

The analysis measures neural correlates of an 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of meaningless actions — a study of imitation drive — not tasks or contrasts probing affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, bonding). Although the sample and analysis appear to be healthy, whole-brain, task-evoked correlations, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level analysis in healthy adults (voxelwise correlations with 'urge to imitate'), the task probes spontaneous motor imitation of meaningless bimanual actions rather than an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals. The contrast does not assess social communication (receptive or productive facial/non‑facial communication) as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

Healthy adult participants; the reported analysis is a whole-brain, voxelwise correlation of task-evoked activation with participants' 'urge to imitate' during observation/imitation, which probes spontaneous imitation — a social processing/social-communication-related task. It is not an ROI, resting-state, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Healthy adult participants performed an observation/ imitation task (action perception). The reported analysis is a whole-brain, group-level univariate correlation of task-evoked activation with 'urge' (not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast). This fits the 'Action Perception' subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others.

Healthy adult sample; group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analysis correlating task-evoked activation with 'urge to imitate' (not an ROI or seed-based connectivity). The task probes imitation/perception of others (a social processing construct), so it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level correlation in healthy adults, the task measures an urge to imitate meaningless actions (spontaneous imitation) rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

Although the study used healthy adults and reports whole-brain, within-group correlations, the task probes spontaneous imitation of meaningless bimanual actions (urge to imitate), not an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior. This does not meet the Social Communication construct (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals), so it should be excluded.

This analysis correlates whole-brain, group-level task-evoked activation with participants' self-rated 'urge to imitate' (an internal self-report of an internal state), in a healthy adult sample. It is not an ROI or resting-state/seed connectivity analysis and thus meets the inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Self (self-monitoring/internal state).

This is a within-group, voxelwise fMRI analysis in healthy adult participants mapping brain activation correlated with the urge to imitate observed actions. It is a whole-brain univariate task-evoked result (not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast) and concerns perception/processing of others' actions (Action Perception), so it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The analysis examines brain correlates of an 'urge to imitate' during observation of meaningless bimanual actions — a sensorimotor/imitation task, not a measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although the sample and analysis appear to be healthy adult, whole-brain data, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

The analysis label is "Familiarity: Observation," which targets familiarity of observed actions rather than a judgment or introspection about the self. Although the table caption mentions correlations with "Urge," the annotation instructions prioritize the analysis name/description; this contrast does not measure self‑related processing (agency/self‑knowledge or current internal states about the self) required for the perception_self category.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level fMRI analysis in healthy adults, the task measures spontaneous imitation of meaningless bimanual actions and participants' "urge to imitate," which does not constitute exchange of socially relevant information or reception/production of facial or non-facial communicative signals. Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure Social Communication.

This analysis reports a group-level, voxelwise correlation between brain activation and participants' 'urge to imitate' during an observation/imitation task in healthy adults. The task probes imitation/perception of others' actions, which falls under social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, within-group univariate correlation in healthy adults, the task and contrast index an urge to imitate meaningless actions (imitation drive), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criterion for affiliation_attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with subjects' self-reported 'urge to imitate' — an introspective/internal state reflecting self-awareness. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task analysis in healthy adults: activation correlated with participants' 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. Imitation relates to social processing (supports social interaction/communication), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain correlation between task-evoked activation and subjective 'urge to imitate' in healthy adult participants during observation/imitation of others' actions. The task probes Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and likely reports whole-brain voxelwise correlations, the task measured urge to imitate meaningless bimanual actions (motor imitation) rather than an exchange of socially relevant communicative signals. This does not meet the provided definition of Social Communication (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communicative acts), so it should be excluded.

Healthy adult participants; analysis reports group-level voxelwise task-evoked correlations (brain activation correlated with urge to imitate) rather than ROI or connectivity. The task involves observing and imitating others' actions, which falls under the Action Perception subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate analysis in healthy adults linking brain activation to participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal cognitive/emotional state). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and the contrast measures a self-related internal state, so it fits the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

This is a group-level, voxelwise task analysis in healthy adult participants examining brain activation correlated with the subjective 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of others' actions. Imitation/urge to imitate is a social-cognitive process (fits social processing), and the result reported is whole-brain univariate activation (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole‑brain, group‑level task correlation in healthy adults (so it meets the sample and analysis-type criteria), the task indexes an 'urge to imitate' meaningless bimanual actions rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or explicit communicative behavior. The social_communication construct targets receptive/productive facial and non‑facial communicative processes (e.g., recognition, gaze, communicative interactions), whereas this study probes motor imitation drive/voluntary action per se. Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Social Communication.

The analysis measures neural correlates of an "urge to imitate" during observation/imitation of meaningless actions — a spontaneous imitation task — not a measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger). Although it appears to be a group-level whole-brain correlation in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activity with participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' — an internal self-evaluative state (self-knowledge/self-monitoring). It is not an ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

The analysis examines brain activation correlated with an 'urge to imitate' during observation/imitation of meaningless actions in healthy adults. Although whole-brain and univariate, the task measures spontaneous imitation drive, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., no measures of close relationships, kinship, loved-one vs stranger, or bonding). Therefore it does not meet the task-domain inclusion criteria for 'affiliation_attachment.'

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, within-group map in healthy adults, the task probes spontaneous motor imitation of meaningless bimanual actions and an internal 'urge to imitate' rather than exchange or perception/production of socially relevant communicative signals. It does not assess social-communication (receptive or productive facial/non-facial communication) as defined by the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activation with participants' self-rated 'urge to imitate' during an imitation task. Although the actions were meaningless, spontaneous imitation taps social/action-perception processes (understanding/responding to others' actions), so it meets the social-related task requirement and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Healthy adult participants; group-level voxelwise brain-behavior correlation (activation correlated with reported 'urge' during observation/imitation) from a task that involves perceiving others' actions (action perception subconstruct). This is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Healthy adult participants; group-level voxelwise whole-brain analysis reporting areas whose activation correlated with self-reported 'urge to imitate' during observation/ imitation of others' actions (an Action Perception task). This is a task-evoked univariate contrast (not ROI, not connectivity, not a between-group comparison), so it fits the Perception/Understanding of Others (Action Perception) inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults linking brain activation to participants' self-reported 'urge to imitate' (an internal subjective state/self-evaluation). That maps onto Perception and Understanding of Self (self-awareness/internal states) and does not fall into ROI, connectivity, or between-group exclusion criteria.

The contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) tests action perception/kinematic processing (observing hand actions), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, within-subject task contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexing perception of others' hand actions (a social-processing construct: perception/understanding of others). It is reported as a voxelwise whole-brain contrast (PFWE-corrected) rather than an ROI or connectivity analysis, and the experiment refers to the healthy subject sample (Experiment 1), not a patient-vs-control comparison. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes perception of others' hand actions, not self-related processing (agency or self-knowledge). Although it is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast indexes action observation / kinematic perception of hand movements, not an exchange of socially relevant information or a communicative signal as defined by the "social_communication" construct. This contrast (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) indexes action perception/kinematics (observing hand actions) rather than affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole‑brain, group-level task contrast in healthy subjects, the task does not probe social bonding/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes observation of others' hand actions (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) in healthy subjects — a task probing perception of others' actions, not self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge). This contrast reflects action observation (ActionOBS–CtrlOBS) — a perceptual/motor action observation task — not an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults, the contrast probes retaliation/anger responses to provocation (losing against provoking vs non‑provoking opponents). It examines emotion and aggressive behavior rather than processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self construct.

Healthy adult sample (15 healthy males); contrast is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked comparison (lost vs opponent types) reported with Talairach cluster coordinates and t-values; task involves social interaction/competition (provoking vs non-provoking opponent), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (competition/provocation). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the study used healthy adult participants and reports whole-brain group-level task activations, the task and contrast (retaliation in response to provocation / aggression) measure retaliation/aggression, not affiliation or attachment (positive social bonding). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the affiliation_attachment category.

Although this is a whole-brain group analysis on healthy adults, the contrast indexes retaliation/aggressive responding (behavioral reaction to provocation) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-judgment, agency or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast indexes retaliation/aggression in response to provocation rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior (facial or non‑facial reception/production). Therefore it does not meet the defined "social_communication" construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from healthy adult participants engaging in a social interaction paradigm (provoking vs non‑provoking opponent) that measures retaliatory responses — a form of social/competitive behavior related to perception and responses to others. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and thus meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Meets inclusion criteria: group-level whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult participants (15 healthy males), derived from a social interaction/provocation task (retaliation toward a provoking opponent) that indexes social processing. Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast from a sample of healthy adult participants (15 healthy male volunteers) examining retaliation during interactive provocation vs non-provocation. The task involves social interaction (response to an opponent/provocation), so the contrast indexes social processing (retaliation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes retaliation to a provoking opponent (aggression/provocation), not affiliation or attachment. Although it is a whole-brain group fMRI analysis on healthy adults, the task measures retaliatory aggression rather than positive social bonding/attachment, so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (15 healthy males); the table reports whole-brain group-level univariate activations (Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, t-values) for an interaction with a provoking vs non‑provoking opponent — a within-group task contrast probing social interaction/perception of others (provocation/retaliation). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a task-evoked, group-level whole-brain fMRI contrast in healthy adult volunteers (15 healthy males) comparing interaction with a provoking vs non‑provoking opponent. The task involves social interaction/competition (retaliation to provocation), which fits the Social Communication domain (e.g., cooperation/competition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between‑group analysis.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast from a sample of healthy adult volunteers probing retaliation during interactions with (non-)provoking opponents — a social interaction task measuring social/emotional processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a whole-brain group analysis on healthy adults, the contrast indexes retaliation/response to a provoking opponent (emotional/aggressive interaction) rather than explicit self-related processing (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency or social self-evaluation). It does not appear to measure perception/understanding of the self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This analysis probes retaliation/aggression (interaction with a provoking vs non‑provoking opponent), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved‑one vs stranger). Although it appears to be a whole‑brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task and contrast do not measure affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a whole-brain group-level fMRI contrast from 15 healthy adult participants (healthy males) examining interaction with a provoking vs non‑provoking opponent in a controlled social/aggression paradigm. The task probes social interaction/competition (retaliation in response to an opponent), which falls under the social communication domain (examples include competition/social interaction). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis in healthy adult participants (healthy male volunteers) reporting voxelwise clusters and t-values. The task involves social interaction (retaliation to provocation) and therefore measures social processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group/clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the contrast ('Retaliation interacting with non‑provoking opponent') indexes aggressive/social interaction/retaliation processes toward others rather than processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or agency. It does not operationalize perception/understanding of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis probes retaliation/aggression in response to provocation (provoking vs non‑provoking opponent), not measures of affiliation or attachment (positive social bonds, kinship, close relationships).
