The reported contrast reflects person/other processing (encoding facts about unfamiliar people vs buildings/hammers) rather than processes involving awareness or knowledge about the self. Therefore it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self. (Also the paper emphasizes ATL ROI/conjunction and connectivity approaches, so the table entry may not reflect a whole-brain group-level voxelwise self-related contrast.)

Although the task (encoding facts about people) targets perception/understanding of others in healthy adults, the reported effects in this table were derived using conjunction and region-of-interest approaches rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise contrast. ROI-based results (and non–task-resting analyses noted elsewhere) violate the 'whole-brain evidence'/ROI exclusion criteria, so this analysis should be excluded.

This analysis appears to report person-selective anterior temporal lobe responses derived with region-of-interest and resting-state connectivity approaches rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise contrast. The inclusion criteria require whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts in healthy adults measuring Social Communication. In addition, the task (encoding facts about people vs buildings vs hammers) does not clearly index an exchange of socially relevant information (Social Communication) in the sense defined here. Because it relies on ROI/resting-state analyses and does not meet the whole-brain/task-exchange criteria, it should be excluded.

Although the study tests person-related (social) encoding in healthy adults, the reported analysis relies on region-of-interest and resting-state functional connectivity approaches (and/or ROI-derived ATL activations) rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate task-evoked voxelwise contrast. ROI and resting-state/seed-based connectivity analyses are excluded by the criteria, so this analysis should not be included.

The contrast reflects person-selective semantic processing (facts about unfamiliar people vs buildings/hammers) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, loved one vs stranger). It does not probe attachment/affiliative behavior or relationships, and the reported analyses also rely on conjunction/ROI approaches rather than a whole-brain task specifically assessing affiliation.

Although the sample is healthy adults and the task involves person-related material, the reported analysis was based on ROI/conjunction and supported by resting-state connectivity rather than a group-level, whole‑brain univariate voxelwise task contrast. ROI and resting‑state/seed connectivity analyses are excluded by the criteria, and the task probes person knowledge (semantic/social cognition) rather than an explicit social‑communication contrast.

This analysis does not measure Perception/Understanding of the self. The study contrasts encoding facts about people, buildings, and hammers (person-selective vs other categories) and concludes person-selective ATL responses; it is about processing others/social categories rather than self-related judgments. In addition, the table/analyses emphasize conjunction and ROI results (not a whole‑brain group-level task contrast probing self-processing). Therefore it fails the construct and whole-brain task-contrast inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked (paired t-test, FWE-corrected) contrast in healthy adult participants (omnivores) viewing negative-valence human vs. animal pictures. The task probes perception/understanding of others and empathy for suffering (social processing), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts negative human vs animal suffering images (empathy/affective appraisal), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment category.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts viewing human vs. animal negative-valence images (empathy/affective appraisal of suffering). It does not assess social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchange of socially relevant information) and therefore does not meet the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This contrast (human vs animal negative pictures) probes empathy/affective responses to others (conspecifics vs non-conspecifics), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a healthy, whole-brain, within-group univariate contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self and therefore does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

While the contrast (person > other categories) targets Perception/Understanding of Others in healthy adults, the reported ATL results were derived using region-of-interest approaches (the paper explicitly used ROI analyses alongside conjunctions and the table is ATL-specific). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked map; ROI-based results therefore should be excluded.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adult vegetarians, the task contrasts negative human vs animal suffering images (empathy/affective appraisal), not affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate (paired t-test) within-group contrast in healthy adult vegetarians, comparing viewing human vs. animal negative-valence pictures. The task measures perception/understanding of others (empathy/social processing), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis—therefore it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain paired-contrast (human vs animal negative pictures) in healthy vegetarian adults using task-evoked fMRI. The contrast probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathy for human vs animal suffering), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis—so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain contrast (human vs animal negative pictures) in healthy adult omnivores. The task involves viewing human suffering (perception/assessment of others' emotional states), which maps onto the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This contrast (viewing negative human vs animal pictures in vegetarians) probes affective/empathy responses to suffering, not the exchange or processing of social-communicative signals (e.g., recognition/production of facial or non‑facial communication, cooperation, kinship). Although it is a whole-brain, within-group fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the task does not measure Social Communication per the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This contrast compares responses to human vs animal negative pictures (empathy/response to others), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a within-group whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure 'Perception and Understanding of Self' and thus fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

This contrast probes affective/empathy responses to human vs animal suffering rather than social-communication processes (e.g., reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals). In addition, the map is from a specific dietary subgroup (vegans), not a general healthy/control group generalizable to the healthy adult population. Therefore it fails the task/content and sample/generalizability inclusion criteria.

This contrast (vegans: human vs. animal negative-valence pictures) probes empathy/affective responses to suffering, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole‑brain within‑group contrast on healthy adults, the task/contrast does not measure affiliation/attachment processes, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-group (paired t-test) whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (vegans) viewing human vs. animal negative-affect pictures. The task measures empathy/affective appraisal toward others (social processing: perception/understanding of others), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast — so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast (human vs. animal negative pictures in vegans) probes empathy/affective responses to others (humans vs animals), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge or agency. Although it is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (paired t-test) in healthy adult vegans comparing viewing human vs animal negative-valence pictures. The task probes perception/affective appraisal of others (empathy toward humans/animals), fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, univariate task contrast (animal vs. human negative-valence pictures) in healthy adult omnivores. The task probes empathy/affective appraisal of others (perception/understanding of others), so it meets the social-processing requirement. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts viewing negative human vs animal scenes (affective/empathy appraisal). It does not measure social communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchanges), so it does not meet the Social_Communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (omnivores), the task contrasts viewing human vs animal suffering scenes (empathy/affective appraisal). This does not assess affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the annotation's task/content requirement.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast of responses to human vs animal negative pictures in omnivores (healthy adults), but the task probes empathy/affective responses to others (human vs animal suffering), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore it does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ inclusion criterion.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast (animal vs. human negative-valence pictures) in healthy adult vegetarians, derived from a task probing empathy/perception of others (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (human vs. animal negative-valence pictures) in healthy adult omnivores, probing perception/affective appraisal of other beings (empathy/understanding of others' suffering). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This contrast reflects differential neural responses to human versus animal suffering (empathy/affective appraisal) rather than a task measuring social communication (e.g., reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals, cooperation/kinship/social comparison). Although it is a healthy adult, whole‑brain, within‑group fMRI contrast, the paradigm targets emotional/empathetic processing of negative scenes rather than social-communication exchanges, so it does not meet the "social_communication" inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-group (paired t-test) whole-brain contrast in healthy adult vegetarians comparing brain responses to human vs. animal negative-affect pictures. The task probes perception/understanding of others (empathic appraisal of others' suffering), and the analysis is neither ROI nor connectivity nor a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast probes differential responses to negative-valence human vs animal suffering (empathy/affective appraisal), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, close relationship scales). Although it is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy participants, the task does not target affiliation/attachment processes (and the sample is a specific dietary subgroup), so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

The contrast is a within-group whole-brain comparison of responses to negative human vs animal suffering images in vegans. Although it is a healthy adult, whole-brain task map, the task probes empathy/affective responses to suffering rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

This is a within-group contrast of responses to human vs. animal negative pictures in vegetarians, which probes empathy/affective appraisal of others (conspecifics vs non-conspecifics), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task measures Perception and Understanding of Self. (Additionally, the sample is a specific dietary subgroup rather than a general healthy control group, weakening generalizability.)

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adult (vegan) subjects, the task contrasts viewing negative human vs animal pictures (empathy/affective appraisal of suffering) rather than measuring social communication (exchange or reception/production of socially relevant communicative signals). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast index Social Communication.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast of responses to human vs. animal negative pictures in vegans assessing empathy/affective responses to others (conspecifics vs non-conspecifics). It does not measure Perception/Understanding of the self (self-knowledge or agency), so it fails the task-domain requirement. (Note: although it is a healthy non-clinical sample, the primary reason for exclusion is that the contrast is not self-related.)

This is a group-level, within-group (paired t-test) whole-brain contrast in healthy adult participants (vegans, a non-clinical sample). The task contrasts viewing human vs. animal negative-affect scenes, which probes social processing (empathy/perception of others). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a within-group, whole-brain (voxelwise) task contrast in healthy adult omnivores viewing negative human images. The task probes perception/understanding of others and empathy (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level within-subject contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts viewing negative human suffering versus neutral scenes (empathy/affective appraisal), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

Although this is a healthy, whole-brain, within-group fMRI contrast (human negative-valence pictures vs neutral in omnivores), the task probes affective/empathic responses to scenes of human/animal suffering rather than social-communication processes (exchange or reception/production of communicative signals, facial/nonfacial communication, or social interaction scenarios). Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication construct.

Although this is a whole‑brain, within‑group contrast in healthy adults (omnivores), the task contrasts responses to human vs neutral/animal negative pictures (empathy/affective appraisal of others). It does not probe self‑related processes (agency or self‑knowledge) required for the "perception_self" construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI contrast (animal vs. human negative-valence pictures) in a healthy adult group (vegans). The task probes perception/assessment of others' affective states (empathy for suffering), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast on healthy adult vegetarians, the task (viewing negative-valence human/animal suffering images) probes empathy/affective appraisal rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). It therefore does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain (paired t) contrast in healthy adult omnivores comparing human negative-valence pictures to neutral scenes. The task probes perception/affective appraisal of other people (suffering), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, univariate whole-brain contrast (human negative-valence pictures vs neutral) in a healthy adult group (vegetarians). The task probes perception/affective appraisal of other humans (empathy/social perception), which falls under Social Processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or a between-group contrast.

This contrast examines brain responses to negative human (vs neutral/other) pictures—i.e., empathy/social perception of others—not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a within-group, whole-brain healthy adult analysis, it does not measure perception/understanding of the self, so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

Although this is a whole-brain within-group contrast in healthy adult vegetarians, the task (passive viewing of negative human/animal suffering scenes) probes affective appraisal/empathy rather than Social Communication (exchange or reception/production of socially relevant communicative signals). Therefore it does not meet the Social_Communication task requirement.

This is a group-level, within-group (paired t-test) whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult vegetarians (human negative vs neutral pictures). The task probes perception/affective appraisal of others (human suffering), which fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task probes negative affective/empathy for suffering (human vs animal/neutral pictures of mutilation, wounds, etc.), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment task criterion.

Although this is a within‑group, whole‑brain contrast in healthy adult vegans (human negative‑valence vs neutral pictures), the task probes affective/empathic responses to suffering rather than Social Communication (exchange or recognition of communicative signals). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure Social Communication.

This is a group-level, whole-brain within-group (paired t) contrast in healthy adult participants (vegans) viewing negative human pictures versus neutral scenes. The task assesses perception/empathy for other humans (social processing: perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This contrast probes responses to negative/affective (suffering) pictures (empathy/affective appraisal), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain, within-group analysis on healthy adults, the task and contrast do not assess affiliation/attachment constructs.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI contrast (animal negative-valence pictures vs neutral) in healthy adult omnivores, assessing responses to others' suffering (animals) — a social/empathy-related process (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (paired t-test, FWE-corrected) within-group contrast in healthy adult vegans comparing human negative-valence images to neutral images. The task probes perception of others' suffering/emotional states (empathy), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain, within-group contrast, the task contrasts negative affective pictures of animals (vs neutral landscapes) and probes empathy/affective appraisal rather than social-communication processes (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative signals or exchange of socially relevant information). Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication construct criteria.

This contrast (animal vs. neutral pictures in omnivores) probes affective/empathic responses to others (animals vs humans), not self-related processing or judgments about the self. Although it is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast on healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

The contrast is a within-group response to negative human (vs neutral/animal) images — an empathy/affect-for-others task, not a measure of perception/understanding of the self. Although it is a whole-brain, within-group map in healthy participants (vegans), it does not index self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge) required for the "perception_self" annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain (voxelwise) paired t-contrast in healthy adult omnivores (animal negative-valence pictures vs neutral), indexing perception/affective appraisal of others (animal suffering). It is task-evoked, not ROI or connectivity and therefore meets the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion criteria.

Although this is a within-group, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts negative human vs animal suffering images (empathy/affective appraisal of suffering). This does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation) as required by the inclusion criteria, so it should be excluded.

This contrast (vegetarians viewing animal vs. neutral negative pictures) measures affective/empathy responses to images, not social communication (no exchange or reception/production of communicative signals). Additionally the analysis is reported for a dietary subgroup (vegetarians) rather than an unselected healthy adult sample, so it does not meet the sample/generalizability requirement. Therefore it should be excluded from the social_communication annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise contrast (paired t-test, FWE-corrected) in a healthy adult subgroup (vegetarians) viewing negative animal scenes versus neutral scenes. The task probes perception/affective responses to others (empathic/social processing), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast reflects viewing others' (human vs animal) negative affective scenes (empathy/affective appraisal), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain, within-group analysis on healthy adults, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the annotation criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, within‑group contrast in healthy adult vegans, the task contrasts negative human/animal suffering images versus neutral scenes (empathy/affective appraisal). It does not probe affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/domain requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain (paired t-test, FWE-corrected) univariate contrast in healthy adult vegetarians viewing negative-valence animal (others) pictures. The task probes perception/affective appraisal of others' suffering (empathy/understanding of others' emotional states). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, whole-brain fMRI contrast of responses to negative-valence pictures of animals (vegans), but the task measures affective/empathic responses to suffering rather than an exchange or processing of social-communication signals (e.g., facial or non-facial communicative acts, kinship/cooperation scenarios). Therefore it does not meet the annotation's Social Communication task requirement.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise fMRI contrast (paired t-test, FWE-corrected) in a healthy adult subgroup (vegans) during viewing of negative animal scenes. The task probes empathy/affective appraisal for others (perception/understanding of others), which falls under Social Processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult subjects (vegans) viewing negative-valence animal pictures versus neutral, which probes perception/affective appraisal of others (animal suffering) — fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct (animacy/empathy). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

This contrast probes affective/empathic responses to images of humans vs animals (others), not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. In addition, the reported map is from a specific subgroup (vegans) rather than a general healthy/control sample, which violates the sample/generalizability requirement. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, univariate whole-brain contrast (dynamic > static facial expressions) from the healthy/control participants. The task involves processing facial expressions (a social perception/emotion recognition task), so it meets the social processing domain. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast (dynamic > static facial expressions) from the healthy control group, and it measures reception of facial communication (processing of dynamic facial expressions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast tests dynamic versus static emotional facial expressions (fear/happiness), which probes general emotion/social perception rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved‑one vs stranger, kinship, bonding). In addition the study involves a clinical ASD group and controls; unless a specific within‑control whole‑brain map for an affiliation task is reported (it is not), the analysis does not meet the task/domain requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' annotation.

This is a group-level, within-control (healthy adults) whole-brain contrast (dynamic > static facial expressions). The task measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states (facial expression processing) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast concerns viewing dynamic versus static facial expressions (processing others' emotional faces), which indexes social perception of others rather than self-awareness/self-knowledge. Additionally the study includes an ASD clinical group (and likely reported between-group comparisons), so it does not clearly represent a whole-brain group-level map of healthy adults on a self-perception task. Therefore it fails the content and sampling inclusion criteria for "perception_self."

Excluded. The contrast involves clinical (ASD) participants and comparisons with controls rather than a healthy-only sample, and the task (dynamic vs static facial emotion expressions) targets emotion processing rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the sample or task inclusion criteria.

The study involves participants with autism spectrum disorder and matched controls. The table caption and study focus indicate clinical vs. control comparisons; no clear evidence that this entry is a whole‑brain, within‑group map from a healthy adult sample alone. Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the analysis be a whole‑brain group contrast generalizable to healthy adults (and may reflect patient or between‑group effects).

The study sample includes individuals with ASD and matched controls and the table caption does not explicitly state this contrast/map is from the healthy control group alone. The inclusion criteria require a whole‑brain, group‑level univariate map from a healthy adult (control) sample only. Because the analysis is drawn from a clinical/comparison study and it is not clearly a control‑only within‑group contrast, it should be excluded.

This analysis reports group × condition interactions from a study comparing ASD and control participants (dynamic vs static facial expressions). Although the task is social, the analysis is a between-group interaction (clinical vs control) rather than a whole-brain univariate map from a healthy adult sample alone, so it fails the sample and exclusion criteria.

Excluded: this analysis reports a group × presentation-condition interaction from a study comparing ASD and control groups (a between-group interaction), not a whole-brain within-group contrast in healthy adults. The task (dynamic vs static facial expressions of fear/happiness) is general emotion/face processing, not an explicit affiliation/attachment task. These violate the sample and analysis inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports a group × condition interaction (ASD vs control for dynamic vs static facial expressions), i.e. a between-group contrast involving a clinical sample rather than a whole-brain univariate map from healthy adults alone, which violates the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (dynamic vs. static facial expressions) comes from a study that includes individuals with ASD and matched controls, but the analysis description does not specify that this is a group-level, whole-brain map from the healthy/control group alone. Because the sample/source is not clearly a healthy adult within-group map (and may reflect patient data or between-group effects), it does not meet the 'Sample' inclusion criterion for perception_others.

This analysis reports a group × presentation interaction (ASD vs controls) for dynamic vs static facial expressions. It is a between-group interaction (clinical vs control) rather than a whole-brain, within-group map from a healthy adult sample, and the task probes perception of others' facial expressions (not self-related processes). Therefore it fails the sample and analysis-type inclusion criteria for perception_self.

This analysis reports a group × presentation-condition interaction (ASD vs control) rather than a whole-brain, group-level task contrast from healthy participants alone. The inclusion criteria require a healthy/control group main effect or within-group whole-brain contrast; between-group contrasts/interactions are explicitly excluded.

The contrast is a whole-brain, group-level univariate task activation (ToM > R) assessing Theory of Mind, which is a core social-processing construct (perception/understanding of others). The table and caption indicate whole-brain voxelwise results in presumably healthy adult participants and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a general Theory-of-Mind (mentalizing) contrast (ToM > R). Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not target affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation) as required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it should not be annotated as affiliation_attachment.

The contrast (dynamic vs. static facial expressions) probes perception of others' emotional faces (social/perceptual processing), not self-awareness or self-knowledge. In addition, the study involves an ASD clinical group and controls (and the table likely reports clinical/group-related analyses), so it does not meet the requirement of a whole-brain, within-group analysis solely in healthy adults.

This is a whole-brain, group-level within-subject contrast (ToM > R) in healthy adults and probes Theory-of-Mind/mentalization, which fits the social_communication construct (reception of non‑facial social information/attribution of mental states). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) whole-brain group map, which probes attribution of mental states to others (other-focused mentalizing), not perception/understanding of the self. Although it meets sample and whole-brain criteria, it does not measure self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge) required for the "perception_self" construct.

This is a within-group, whole-brain fMRI contrast (ToM > R) indexing Theory-of-Mind processing (Understanding Mental States), reported with whole-brain voxelwise thresholds. It matches the Perception/Understanding of Others construct and is not a ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. The available metadata implies a healthy adult sample and a task-based ToM contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM) task contrast (ToM > R), not a task or contrast specifically assessing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain healthy-group analysis, the cognitive domain does not match the affiliation/attachment criteria.

The item describes a Bayesian comparison of responses between two regions (mPFC vs. right STG) for the ToM>R contrast — i.e., a region-to-region/ROI-style test — rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain voxelwise map. Per the criteria, ROI/region comparisons are excluded, so this analysis should not be included despite involving a social (ToM) task.

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) analysis probing mentalizing about others (and a Bayesian comparison between mPFC and rSTG responses), not a task/contrast that measures perception or understanding of the self. Although it appears to be a healthy, whole-brain group analysis, it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast target self-related processes, so it should be excluded from the "perception_self" annotation.

This is a group-level, within-subjects whole-brain contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult pairs performing an on-line eye-contact task, which is clearly a social interaction measure (mutual eye gaze). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although the analysis tests a Theory-of-Mind (ToM > R) effect, the described analysis is a Bayesian comparison of responses between two regions (mPFC vs right STG) rather than a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain univariate contrast. This is effectively an ROI/region-to-region test, which falls under the exclusion criteria (ROI analyses).

The contrast is a Theory-of-Mind (mentalizing) task (ToM > R). Although it is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast, the annotation target is "social_communication" (receptive/production of facial or non‑facial communication). The ToM/mentalizing contrast does not specifically measure social communication per the provided inclusion examples, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-subject, group-level contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) from healthy adult pairs measuring mutual eye contact — a form of facial social communication (production/reception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (LIVE > REPLAY) and concerns social interaction (mutual eye gaze), the task does not directly measure affiliation or attachment per the annotation definition (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, cooperation/competition, loved one vs stranger). The contrast probes on-line mutual gaze and perceptual-motor coupling rather than measures of social bonding/attachment, so it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast specifically index affiliation/attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult pairs performing real-time mutual eye-gaze. The task probes perception/action of another person (online social/eye-contact interaction), fitting the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The analysis explicitly tests enhanced effective connectivity (directional/seed-based connectivity) from the ACC in the LIVE condition. The exclusion criteria disallow seed-based/effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI, DCM), so this is not a whole-brain univariate task-evoked activation map and must be excluded despite the social task.

This analysis reports enhanced effective (directed) connectivity from the ACC (a seed-based/effective connectivity result). The exclusion criteria explicitly disallow seed-based or effective connectivity analyses (e.g., PPI/DCM), so it does not meet the whole-brain univariate task-evoked map requirement despite the task being social (eye contact).

This is a group-level univariate whole-brain contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult participants and is not an ROI or connectivity-only analysis. The LIVE mutual eye‑gaze condition is interpreted by the authors as engaging self‑awareness/self‑monitoring mechanisms (ACC/AIC, limbic mirror system), so the contrast maps onto the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

The analysis is an effective/seed-based connectivity analysis (“enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC”), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. Connectivity/seed-based/effective connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded by the criteria, so this should not be included.

This analysis reports enhanced effective (seed-based) connectivity from the ACC in the LIVE condition. The annotation requires group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise contrasts. Seed-based/effective connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded, so this entry should not be included.

This analysis reports enhanced effective connectivity from the ACC (a seed-based/effective-connectivity result), which falls under excluded analyses. The inclusion criteria require group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise maps; seed-based/effective connectivity analyses are explicitly excluded despite the task involving social perception.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain within-group contrast (LIVE > REPLAY), the task probes realtime mutual eye-gaze/sensorimotor synchrony rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation/competition, loved-one vs stranger, or bonding/attachment scales). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure Affiliation and Attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (LIVE > REPLAY) in healthy adult participants indexing neural responses to real-time mutual eye contact. The task probes perception/action of another person (eye contact, partner-directed attention) and thus fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

The analysis as named is an interbrain synchronization (between-subject connectivity) contrast (LIVE>REPLAY), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task activation map. That makes it a connectivity/synchronization analysis, which falls under the exclusion criteria (seed-/between-brain connectivity/effective connectivity), so it should not be included despite the task being social (eye contact) and the sample being healthy adults.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate contrast (social interaction > non-social interaction) in presumably healthy adult participants, probing perception/understanding of others (social interaction processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The analysis is described as identifying regions with enhanced interbrain synchronization (LIVE vs REPLAY), i.e. a connectivity/synchronization measure rather than a group-level univariate whole‑brain task-evoked contrast tapping explicit self-perception. This falls under excluded connectivity/interbrain synchronization analyses and does not clearly index Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a whole-brain, group-level random-effects univariate contrast (social interaction > non-social interaction) in a healthy adult sample. The task probes perception/reception of interactions (body-language/point-light displays), which fits the 'Reception of Non-Facial Communication' subconstruct of Social Communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, random-effects group contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts observing social interactions versus non-interactions but does not specifically probe affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

The contrast indexes perception of social interactions between two agents (observing others interacting vs acting independently), i.e. perception of others' interactions, not processes of self-awareness, agency, self-knowledge or judgments about the self. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group task contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required.

This is a whole-brain, random-effects group-level univariate contrast (social interaction > non-social interaction) assessing perception of interactions between agents. It targets perception/understanding of others (action/animacy/social interaction), is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is consistent with a healthy adult task sample, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (20 healthy male volunteers); group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (CV > NV) with voxelwise FWE-corrected results; task explicitly probes empathy/social cognition (campaign vs neutral videos, STS activation linked to empathic responses). Meets inclusion and none of the exclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (CV > NV), the task probes empathy and processing of others (campaign victims) rather than self-awareness, self-monitoring, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the Perception and Understanding of Self construct.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task manipulates empathy elicited by traffic‑awareness campaign videos rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (campaign vs. neutral videos) in healthy adult participants that indexes empathic responses to others (observation of victims/elicitation of empathy). The task probes perception/understanding of others' emotional states (STS activations correlated with empathic expression), so it fits the perception_others inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (Low>High) derived from healthy adult participants viewing animations that manipulate intentionality/agency. The task clearly probes social processing (perception/attribution of intention), and the contrast is not ROI-, connectivity-, or between-group-based, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the sample (healthy adults) and task (live mutual eye contact) are social and appropriate, the analysis is described as measuring interbrain synchronization (a connectivity measure) rather than a group-level univariate whole‑brain task-evoked activation map. Connectivity/interbrain-synchronization analyses fall under the exclusion criteria (seed/effective/connectivity-type analyses), so this analysis should not be included.

The contrast probes agency/intentionality perception in animated shapes (intentional bias/agency attribution), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation). Although it appears to be a group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy participants, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs required by the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast manipulates agency/intentionality attribution for animated shapes (social perception/theory-of-mind) rather than measures of social communication (exchange of socially relevant information, receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication). Thus it does not meet the "social_communication" construct as defined.

The CV>NV contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adult participants (20 males) and probes processing of others' emotional states (empathy induction) from campaign videos. This maps onto social communication (receptive socio-emotional/non‑facial communication), so it meets the inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast).

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level comparison in healthy adults, it manipulates attribution of intentionality to animated shapes (perception of others' agency/intentionality). The construct 'perception_self' targets self-related processes (self-awareness, self-knowledge, or sense of one's own agency). This analysis probes attribution to external agents rather than self-referential processing, so it does not meet the task/content requirement.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (Low-intention > High-intention) from an event-related fMRI study of intentionality/animacy perception using healthy adult participants. The contrast indexes perception/understanding of others (animacy/intentionality) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The High>Low contrast is a group-level, within-subject univariate whole-brain task contrast comparing high- vs low-intention animations (agency attribution), a social-perception task tapping social/intentional processing in (presumably) healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast probes agency attribution/intentionality from animated shapes (social cognition/mentalizing), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, bonding, cooperation). Although it appears to be a healthy, whole-brain group task contrast, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult, group-level whole-brain task contrast (High>Low intention) measuring agency attribution from animated shapes — a form of reception of non‑facial social cues / social interaction perception. Not an ROI, connectivity, or between‑group analysis, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

The High>Low contrast is a group-level, whole-brain univariate comparison of viewing high-intention versus low-intention animated motions (agency/animacy attribution), which directly probes perception/understanding of others (animacy/mental state attribution). Participants are a healthy adult sample and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the contrast is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task probes attribution of agency to animated shapes (perception of others' intentionality/social stimuli), not processes of self-awareness, self-monitoring, or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (females: own body perception > scrambled) from a healthy adult sample. The task probes perception/understanding of the self (own body perception), which falls under Social Processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults (female participants) comparing own-body perception to scrambled images. The task probes self-perception/self-knowledge (own body perception), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast — so it meets the inclusion criteria for "perception_self."

The contrast is own body perception versus scrambled images — a self/body-recognition task, not a measure of affiliation or attachment (social bonds, kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation, etc.). Although it is a group-level whole-brain activation in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment processes, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own-body perception versus a scrambled image (self-recognition/body perception), not a social-communication task or contrast (no exchange or reception/production of socially relevant information or social comparison). Although the sample and analysis type appear acceptable, the task does not measure social communication as defined, so it should be excluded.

This contrast indexes own-body (self) perception (own body > scrambled) in healthy participants, not perception or understanding of other people. The task/contrast does not measure representations about others (e.g., others' states, traits, or actions), so it does not meet the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own-body perception versus scrambled images (self-body recognition), not a task or contrast assessing affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although it is a whole-brain, healthy adult group activation, the task targets self/body perception rather than social bonding or attachment, so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, group-level whole-brain contrast, the contrast (own body perception > scrambled image) probes self/body perception (visual/self-recognition) rather than Social Communication (exchange or reception/production of socially relevant signals). It does not measure communicative processes (facial/non‑facial reception or production), so it fails the task-domain inclusion criteria.

Group-level univariate fMRI contrast in healthy adult males (own-body images > scrambled control) directly probes self-perception (own body judgment). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and is therefore consistent with the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The contrast is 'own body perception > scrambled image' (self-perception), not a measure of perceiving or reasoning about others. Although the study examines own vs other bodies overall, this specific analysis indexes self-body perception rather than Perception and Understanding of Others, so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-group univariate whole-brain activation contrast (own body perception > scrambled) reported for healthy adult males (15 subjects). The task probes perception/understanding of the self (own body), which falls under the social-processing domain (Perception and Understanding of Self). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-group whole-brain task contrast in healthy adult participants (females) comparing own-body perception to a scrambled control. Own-body perception maps onto 'Perception and Understanding of Self', which falls under Social Processing. The analysis is not ROI-based, connectivity-based, or a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own-body perception versus scrambled images — a self/body-perception task, not an affiliation/attachment task. Although it appears to be a whole-brain group analysis on healthy adults, it does not assess social bonding, close relationships, kinship, or attachment-related processes, so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion.

The contrast reflects own body perception (self-recognition/perceptual self-processing) versus scrambled images in healthy adults. Although whole-brain and within-group, this task/contrast indexes self/body perception rather than an exchange or reception/production of socially communicative signals, so it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-group whole-brain contrast in healthy adults (female group) comparing own-body perception to a scrambled control, which targets self-related perception/knowledge (own body). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants (own body perception vs scrambled image) and targets perception/understanding of the self — a social-processing construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own-body perception versus scrambled image (self-recognition/body perception), not a measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although it appears to be a within-group whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, it does not assess social bonding/attachment processes required for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

This analysis indexes own-body perception (own body > scrambled image) in healthy males — a self/body-perception contrast, not an exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. It does not assess social-communication constructs (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative information or social comparison contrasts like loved one vs stranger), so it fails the task/content inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own body perception (self) > scrambled image, i.e. self-perception, not perception/understanding of others. Although the study includes other-body conditions, this specific analysis measures self-body perception and therefore does not meet the 'perception_others' inclusion requirement.

This is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain (de)activation contrast in healthy adult males (own body perception > scrambled control). The contrast directly measures self-perception (own body), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the "perception_self" inclusion criteria.

The contrast is own body perception (self) > scrambled image — a self‑perception contrast, not a measure of perceiving or reasoning about other people. Although the task included other‑body stimuli, this specific analysis indexes self‑perception, so it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Others' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, task-evoked univariate contrast (own body perception > scrambled control) in a healthy adult sample. The task assesses perception/understanding of the self (own-body perception), which falls under Social Processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a body localizer contrast (bodies > chairs), which indexes general body/object perception rather than self-related processing (e.g., own-body vs other or own-body vs scrambled). The inclusion criteria require a task/contrast probing Perception and Understanding of Self; this contrast does not meet that requirement.

This contrast is a body/localizer or own-body perception contrast (bodies > chairs or own body > scrambled) assessing visual/self-body perception, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although the sample and whole-brain criteria are met, the task does not probe social bonding/attachment, so it fails the content inclusion criterion.

This contrast indexes own-body perception / body-localizer (own body or bodies > scrambled/chairs) — a perceptual self-recognition/body-processing task, not an exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. Although conducted in healthy adults with whole-brain group contrasts, it does not measure social communication (receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication, social scenarios, cooperation, social comparison), so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (same-sex body images > scrambled control). The task involves own/other body perception—a social-processing construct (perception/understanding of self and others)—and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is an object-category/localizer contrast (bodies > chairs) rather than a task contrast probing perception or understanding of other people (e.g., social comparison, mental state inference, or explicit animacy/social processing). Although bodies are animate, the bodies>chairs localizer is a low-level category contrast and does not specifically measure perception/understanding of others as required by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (own/same‑sex body image vs scrambled control) indexes self/own-body perception rather than an exchange or processing of socially communicative signals. It does not measure Social Communication (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communicative information), so it does not meet the content inclusion criterion.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task probes own/other body perception and self-resemblance (self vs scrambled or same‑sex body vs scrambled). It does not assess affiliation or attachment (no close-relationship/kinship or loved‑one vs stranger contrast), so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

The contrast compares viewing same-sex (other) body images versus scrambled controls in a sample of healthy adults and is reported as a group-level task-evoked fMRI contrast (whole-brain). This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast in healthy adult participants comparing perception of same-sex other bodies vs own body (0% morph), which probes social processing (perception/understanding of self vs others). Although this is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast in healthy adults, the task probes own-body vs other-body perception (self/other body identity and resemblance), not affiliation/attachment (social bonds, close relationships, kinship, or cooperation). Although the sample and analysis appear to be a whole‑brain, group‑level fMRI contrast in healthy adults, the contrast labeled "Same‑sex morph > scramble" indexes perception of same‑sex other bodies (or morphed other images) rather than explicit self‑perception/knowledge. The sample and analysis type are acceptable, but the cognitive construct does not match.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adult participants comparing perception of other people’s bodies (same-sex morph) to own-body images. This is a within-subject, task-evoked contrast from a healthy adult sample comparing perception of same-sex other bodies (morph) to own-body images — a self vs other body judgment relevant to Perception and Understanding of Self. The contrast (opposite-sex body images > scrambled) comes from a body-perception task comparing self/other bodies and does not target affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, close-relationship measures). Although the sample and analysis appear to be whole-brain in healthy adults, the task/contrast does not operationalize affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (opposite-sex body images > scrambled control) in healthy adult participants viewing other people’s bodies. This contrast tests body perception/self–other similarity (viewing opposite‑sex body images versus scrambled controls) rather than an act of social communication (exchange or reception/production of socially meaningful signals such as facial expression, gaze, or explicit social interaction). Although the task involves social stimuli, it is primarily a perceptual/self‑comparison body task and does not match the Social Communication construct as defined, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (images of opposite-sex other bodies > scrambled control) in healthy adult participants. The contrast measures perception of other people’s bodies (i.e., perception of others), not an ROI or between-group effect, and therefore fits the Perception and Understanding of Others category.

This contrast probes own-body versus other-body visual self‑perception (body morphing/self-recognition), not processes of affiliation or attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, loved‑one vs stranger). This is a within-subject, task-evoked contrast (opposite-sex body image > own body) in a healthy adult sample (15 men, 15 women) probing perception of others/the self — a clear social-processing construct (Perception/Understanding of Others). This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants comparing perception of others (opposite-sex bodies) versus own body. This is a within-group, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults comparing perception of opposite-sex other bodies to own-body images — a form of social comparison/self–other processing that falls under the Social Communication construct. This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast in healthy adults (15 M, 15 F) from a task that explicitly probes own-body perception and self-related judgments (rating how much bodies look like oneself). This is a group-level, task-evoked fMRI analysis in healthy adult participants (15M/15F) that examines a parametric modulation of self/other perception (“not me” ratings) during viewing of opposite-sex body morphs. This is a task-evoked, within-group parametric fMRI analysis in healthy adults measuring participants' self-related judgments ("not me" ratings) of opposite-sex body morphs — a direct measure of perception/understanding of the self (self–other comparison). This analysis indexes a within-task, parametric response to images of other people (opposite‑sex morphs) — i.e., perception of others — in a healthy adult sample (15 men, 15 women). Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (same-sex > opposite-sex body images) indexes perceptual/social salience of sex of others rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, parental/peer bonding). This is a between-group contrast (SP < NC) comparing excessive smartphone users to controls, which violates the requirement that analyses be within healthy adults only (no between-group contrasts). This is a group-level, within-subject voxelwise contrast (S-P > fixation) from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using a self/other referential task, which targets perception/understanding of the self (a social-processing construct). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast from healthy adult participants (20 women) using a self‑referential Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing Task (self vs baseline). The contrast S-P > Fixation reflects self-referential (self positive) processing versus baseline, not perception/understanding of others. Although the sample and whole-brain group analysis appear appropriate, the contrast does not measure processing of others (e.g., Other vs Self or Other vs Stranger), so it fails the content inclusion criterion for perception_others.

Although this is a healthy adult, group-level univariate contrast (likely whole-brain S‑P > fixation), the task probes valenced self‑referential processing (self vs unknown other) and individual differences in self‑esteem — not affiliation/attachment or close‑relationship processing (e.g., loved one vs stranger, bonding or attachment measures). The "other" here is an unknown woman, and the paradigm targets self‑esteem, so it does not meet the affiliation/attachment criterion.

This is a within-group, whole‑brain, task-evoked contrast from a healthy adult sample (20 women) using a Visual‑Verbal Self‑Other Referential Processing task. This analysis ('TastinessPositive') indexes neural representations of food tastiness during choices (attribute/value coding), not processes of self-perception/self-knowledge. It does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self. (Also the study emphasizes attribute decoding/decision-value representations rather than a group-level univariate self-related contrast.) This analysis does not meet the inclusion criteria. The analysis (labelled 'Negative') comes from a study of attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices. This analysis does not target Perception and Understanding of Self. It examines attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices (including prosocial attribute coding), not self-awareness/self-knowledge or contrasts like self vs other. In addition, the reported work emphasizes multivariate decoding and attribute-value prediction rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast required by the inclusion criteria.

Insufficient evidence that this is a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map measuring social processing. The table caption refers to trial-wise attribute prediction (and the study emphasizes multivariate decoding), so the reported analysis is likely multivariate (or ROI/searchlight) rather than a voxelwise univariate contrast. Although the study includes altruistic (social) choices, the provided description does not confirm the analysis meets the whole-brain univariate inclusion criterion required for social_processing_all.

Although the study involves altruistic (social) choice, the reported analysis (“neural prediction of trial-wise attribute values”) stems from multivariate decoding/encoding of trial-wise attributes rather than a group-level univariate, voxelwise task contrast generalizable to healthy adults. The inclusion criteria require a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked map; this analysis does not meet that requirement.

The provided analysis label (“Negative”) and table caption describe neural prediction of attribute values in food and altruistic choice, but do not document a group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrast that specifically measures perception/understanding of others. The study focuses on value/attribute representations and multivariate decoding across domains (food vs altruistic choice) rather than an explicit social-perception contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). It is also unclear whether the reported result is a voxelwise univariate map (versus multivariate decoding/ROI/model-based analyses). Because it does not clearly meet the requirement of a whole-brain univariate group-level contrast indexing perception/understanding of others, it should be excluded.

This analysis concerns neural prediction of trial-wise attribute values in food and altruistic choice (value/attribute representation and multivariate decoding) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast of Social Communication. The task is decision-making/altruism (not a social-communication contrast per the construct definition), and the reported analysis appears to be multivariate/attribute-decoding rather than a voxelwise univariate map from healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports multivariate decoding/searchlight prediction of trial-wise attribute values in food and altruistic choices, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast indexing Perception/Understanding of Self. It does not target self‑perception constructs (agency/self‑knowledge) and appears to use multivariate decoding rather than the required univariate voxelwise map, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis reflects multivariate decoding/prediction of trial-wise attribute values (and focuses on attribute-specific neural codes) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast. Although the task includes altruistic choices (a prosocial domain), the analysis is not a voxelwise univariate map of an affiliation/attachment contrast (e.g., Loved one vs Stranger) required by the inclusion criteria, so it should be excluded.

This analysis does not meet the "social_communication" inclusion criteria. The table/abstract describe multivariate decoding of trial-wise attribute values for food and altruistic choices (value/attribute representations), not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast indexing social communication. Also, the task is prosocial decision-making (altruistic choice), which is not equivalent to the Social Communication construct (reception/production of facial or non‑facial communication). Therefore it should be excluded.

The reported analysis appears to be trial-wise neural prediction / multivariate decoding of attribute values across food and altruistic choices, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task-evoked contrast indexing Perception and Understanding of Others. It therefore does not meet the requirement for a whole-brain, univariate voxelwise map of a social/perception contrast (e.g., loved vs stranger or other explicit other‑perception task). The analysis also appears focused on value/attribute representations (and includes non-social food choices), so it does not clearly operationalize the Perception_of_Others construct.

The reported analysis appears to be multivariate decoding/predictive mapping of trial-wise attribute values (including prosocial/altruistic attributes) rather than a group-level univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map. Although the task involves social/prosocial processing in healthy adults, it does not meet the inclusion requirement of a univariate whole-brain group map, so it should be excluded.

This analysis reports neural prediction / multivariate decoding of trial-wise attribute values during food and altruistic choices rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrast measuring self-perception. Although the sample is healthy, the reported analysis is a multivariate/predictive approach (not a voxelwise univariate statistical map) and it addresses attribute representations in choice (prosocial/attribute coding) rather than explicit Perception and Understanding of the Self (self-knowledge or agency) as required by the inclusion criteria.

This analysis reports multivariate decoding/pattern-based prediction of attribute values in food and altruistic choices rather than a group-level univariate, whole‑brain voxelwise task contrast. The task (food/altruistic choice) is not a clear affiliation/attachment paradigm (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation) and the reported results reflect attribute-specific neural codes (MVPA), so it does not meet the requirement for a whole-brain univariate task-evoked map measuring affiliation/attachment.

The reported analysis (neural prediction of trial-wise attribute values) in this study used multivariate decoding approaches to predict attribute representations across dietary and altruistic choices rather than providing a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map. Inclusion criteria require a voxelwise univariate group map measuring social processing in healthy adults; this analysis does not meet the whole-brain univariate map requirement and so should be excluded.

This analysis derives from multivariate decoding of attribute/value representations in food and altruistic choices rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain (voxelwise) task contrast. The task is decision/value-based (altruistic choice) rather than explicitly measuring Social Communication, and the paper reports MVPA/prediction analyses rather than the required univariate whole-brain statistical map. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The analysis comes from a study of value representations in dietary and altruistic choice using multivariate decoding; it does not appear to be a group-level univariate, whole-brain task-evoked contrast targeting affiliation/attachment (e.g., loved one vs stranger or cooperation paradigms). The task is about altruistic/value-based choice (prosocial attributes) rather than explicit affiliation/attachment, and the reported effects arise from multivariate decoding/attribute-prediction methods rather than the required univariate voxelwise maps.

This analysis does not meet the criteria. It reports neural prediction/decoding of trial-wise attribute values during food and altruistic choices (multivariate predictive analyses of choice attributes) rather than a group-level, univariate whole-brain task contrast probing self-perception/self-knowledge. The task targets value/attribute representations (taste, health, prosocial attributes) in choice contexts rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, and the reported analyses appear to be decoding/predictive (not a voxelwise group univariate map). Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (observing a human > robot agent) from an fMRI study on social perception/animacy in healthy adults. The contrast indexes perception/understanding of others (social processing), and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis tests neural prediction/encoding of trial-wise attribute values (food and altruistic choice) using multivariate decoding/value-representation approaches, not a group-level univariate whole-brain task contrast measuring perception or understanding of others. The contrast is about attribute/value representations (not an explicit Perception/Understanding of Others contrast such as loved one vs stranger or theory-of-mind judgments), and the study emphasizes multivariate decoding rather than a univariate voxelwise map generalizable to the healthy population. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the "perception_others" annotation.

This analysis concerns neural representations of attribute values during value-based (food and altruistic) choice and uses multivariate decoding/valuation approaches rather than an explicit task contrast measuring perception or understanding of others (e.g., mentalizing, kinship, cooperation contrasts). It therefore does not meet the requirement for a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked map indexing Perception and Understanding of Others.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (human > robot), the task probes animacy/person perception and belief about agent origin, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., no measures of kinship, close relationships, cooperation/competition or loved‑one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the affiliation/attachment task criterion.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults (observing human > robot actions), the task probes person perception/animacy and action observation/mentalizing rather than Social Communication (exchange of socially relevant information, facial/non‑facial communicative reception or production). The contrast does not index a social-communication process (e.g., communication, gaze/expressive exchange, kinship, cooperation), so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise univariate contrast (robot > human agent) from an fMRI task in which participants observed actions by human vs robot agents — a clear social perception/understanding-of-others task. The table caption indicates whole-brain results (voxel-level thresholding) rather than ROI or connectivity, and the study concerns healthy adult participants. Thus it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (observing human > robot agent) from healthy adult participants probing action/animacy perception (perception of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain group contrast, the contrast (robot > human agent) indexes perception of animacy/agent form, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). It does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it should be excluded.

This contrast (observing a human > robot agent) indexes perception of others' actions/animacy, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (robot > human agent; action observation/animacy perception) probes person perception/mentalizing and animacy cues rather than social communication (exchange of socially relevant information, facial/non‑facial communicative reception or production). It does not target a social-communication task/contrast (e.g., affect recognition, gaze/reciprocity, loved one vs stranger), so it fails the annotation's task inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (robot > human agent) from an fMRI task where participants observed actions, which maps onto Action Perception (a subconstruct of Perception and Understanding of Others).
