The sample appears to be healthy adults and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (main effect of belief: human motion-capture > computer-generated animation) from a healthy adult fMRI study probing perception of animacy/agenthood. The task is social (social perception/mentalizing about agents) and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast (observing robot > human agent) probes perception of others/agent form (animacy/person perception) rather than processes involving awareness, judgment, or representation of the self. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy adult group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (belief that actions were made by human motion capture vs computer-generated animation) probes animacy/person-perception and action observation/mentalizing rather than exchange or processing of communicative signals. It does not measure social communication (receptive or productive facial/non‑facial communicative behaviors), so it fails the content-based inclusion criterion.

This contrast tests belief about agent origin (human motion-capture vs computer-generated animation) in an action-observation/animacy task rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation/competition). Although it is a whole-brain group task contrast in healthy adults, it does not target affiliation/attachment processes, so it should be excluded.

The contrast reflects belief about the animacy/origin of observed agents (human motion capture > computer-generated animation) — a person-perception/animacy manipulation about others, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although healthy subjects and whole-brain group analyses were used, the task measures perception of others, so it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' criterion.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (human motion-capture belief > computer-generated animation belief) indexing participants' beliefs about the animacy/origin of observed actions. It targets animacy/action perception (Perception and Understanding of Others), uses healthy adult subjects, and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (computer-generated animation > human motion-capture belief) from a healthy adult sample probing beliefs about animacy. The task probes person perception/mentalizing (perception and understanding of others), so it meets the social-processing construct. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast, so it satisfies the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain group-level univariate contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts belief about agent origin (computer-generated animation vs human motion capture) and probes animacy/person-perception and mentalizing. It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation), so it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria for 'affiliation_attachment'.

This contrast compares beliefs about agents (computer-generated animation > human motion capture) — i.e., perception of others' animacy — not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (computer-generated animation > human motion-capture belief) from a healthy adult sample probing knowledge cues to animacy. The task measures perception/understanding of others (animacy/action perception), and it is not an ROI/ connectivity or clinical between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain contrast of belief about agent animacy (computer-generated animation vs human motion capture) during action observation. While it probes person perception/mentalizing, it does not measure social communication (exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behaviors) as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (interaction) from an fMRI task probing perception of agents/animacy (human vs robot and belief manipulations), i.e., social perception/understanding of others, sampled in healthy adults. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults probing perception of others (animacy/action observation) — an interaction comparing congruent vs incongruent agent/belief pairings. It assesses animacy/action perception (Perception and Understanding of Others) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the contrast probes animacy/agent perception and belief manipulation (person perception, action observation, mentalizing) rather than an exchange of socially relevant information or communicative behavior. It does not measure Social Communication per the annotation definition, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (interaction of agent form and belief manipulation) from a healthy adult sample, probing perception/mentalizing about human vs. robot animacy — a clear social-processing task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or clinical between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This contrast tests effects of agent form and belief about animacy (congruent vs incongruent human/robot and belief pairings) during action observation — a perceptual/mentalizing manipulation about animacy. It does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the task/content requirement for the affiliation_attachment label.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task manipulates perceived animacy/belief about agent origins (congruent vs incongruent agent/belief pairings). It does not measure affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger), so it fails the task/content inclusion criterion.

The contrast tests effects of agent form and belief about agent animacy (human vs robot; motion-capture vs computer-generated) — i.e., perception of others/animacy and an interaction between stimulus and belief. It does not probe self-related processes (self-awareness, agency, self-knowledge, social comparison or other self-focused judgments). Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, it does not meet the content requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the contrast probes perception of animacy and belief manipulations (agent form × belief congruency) / person perception and mentalizing, not exchanges of socially relevant information or communication (facial/non‑facial reception or production, cooperation/competition, kinship scenarios, etc.). Therefore it does not meet the Social Communication task/contrast requirement.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain, group-level contrast, the contrast probes perception of agent animacy and belief congruency (human vs robot form and belief about motion origin) — i.e., perception of others/agents — not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency relating to the participant. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast (interaction) from a healthy-adult sample examining perception of agents' animacy/action (human vs robot and belief manipulations). The contrast probes perception/understanding of others (animacy/action perception) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets inclusion criteria.

The study and table report neural responses to linguistic and emotional prosody in high-functioning autism and controls — not tasks probing affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although there may be a healthy control group, the contrast/task does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it fails the task-domain inclusion criterion.

The contrast concerns prosodic (linguistic/emotional) speech processing, which is a social-communication / emotion-recognition task and thus measures social processing. The table reports brain activation in controls (healthy participants) rather than only a patient-vs-control comparison, and the analysis is presented as group-level task-evoked activations (whole-brain). Therefore it meets the sample (healthy adults), task (social processing), and whole-brain, within-group criteria. (If instead the particular entry is a between-group contrast or an ROI-only result, it should be excluded.)

This analysis probes prosodic (linguistic/emotional) speech processing in a study including high‑functioning autism (HFA) participants and controls, not tasks that measure self‑related perception/understanding. The sample is a clinical vs control comparison (not a healthy‑only group generalizable to the healthy adult population), and the task content is prosody/emotion rather than self‑knowledge/agency or social self‑comparison. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

The analysis reports group-level whole-brain activation for the healthy/control group (separate from the HFA group) during prosodic speech processing. Prosodic/emotional speech is a form of non‑facial social communication (receptive), the map is a univariate task-evoked contrast from controls (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast), and is therefore consistent with the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The study and table explicitly involve a clinical group (high-functioning autism) alongside controls and the table caption refers to activations in HFA and controls. Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults only (not clinical groups or comparisons). Because the analysis appears to involve a clinical vs. control context (or at least includes a clinical group), it does not meet the sample criterion and should be excluded.

The reported analysis comes from an fMRI study of linguistic/emotional prosody in high-functioning autism and controls. Although a 'Controls' group is present, the task measures prosodic speech processing rather than affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the task/contrast inclusion criterion for affiliation_attachment (and the table also reports clinical vs control data).

This is a within-group, whole-brain activation map from the healthy control participants (the table reports '...in controls'), not an ROI or connectivity analysis or a between-group contrast. The task probes prosodic and emotional prosody processing (receptive non‑facial social communication), which fits the social_communication construct (reception of non‑facial communication). Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked activation map from the healthy control group during prosodic (including emotional prosody) speech processing. Emotional/linguistic prosody involves perception/understanding of others’ social signals, meeting the Social Processing construct. The report appears to be whole‑brain group activation (not ROI or connectivity) and is not a between-group contrast. (Note: this decision assumes the controls are healthy adults as matched to the HFA sample; if participants are non‑adult, it would not meet the 'adult participants' inclusion criterion.)

This analysis concerns neural responses to linguistic/emotional prosody in controls (speech prosody perception), not tasks or contrasts that probe Perception and Understanding of the Self (e.g., self vs other, social comparison, kinship scenarios). Although it likely is a healthy control group whole-brain map, it does not measure self-related processes required for the "perception_self" label.

The reported analysis reflects brain areas commonly activated in HFA (a clinical group) and controls (i.e., a conjunction across clinical and healthy participants), not a group-level whole-brain map derived solely from a healthy adult sample. Therefore it fails the 'Sample' inclusion criterion requiring analyses on healthy adults only and is not generalizable as a healthy/control-only task-evoked map.

This analysis reports activations in high-functioning autism (HFA) and controls (a clinical vs control context) and is not an exclusive healthy-adult group-level map. Moreover the task probes prosodic speech (linguistic/emotional prosody), not an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, cooperation, loved-one vs stranger). Thus it fails the sample and task-domain inclusion criteria.

The reported analysis concerns activations 'commonly activated in HFA and controls' (i.e., includes a clinical group) rather than a group-level whole-brain map from healthy/control participants alone. The inclusion criteria require analyses be from healthy adults only (not clinical/comparison samples), so this analysis should be excluded.

This analysis reports brain activations in high-functioning autism (HFA) and controls (a clinical vs. control conjunction/comparison) for prosodic speech processing, not a task probing self-perception/understanding. Inclusion requires a whole-brain group map from healthy adults only and a self-related task/contrast. The sample and task here do not meet those criteria.

Insufficient evidence that this specific contrast measures Perception and Understanding of Others. The study targets prosodic (linguistic and emotional) speech, but the analysis is only labeled “Controls” with no explicit contrast (e.g., emotional prosody > neutral) showing perception of others' emotional states. Without a clear task/contrast assessing others' mental or emotional states, it does not meet the annotation criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) comparing a clinical group (high‑functioning autism) to controls rather than a group-level whole‑brain univariate map from a healthy sample alone. The inclusion criteria require maps from healthy adult participants (or within‑group healthy contrasts); between‑group patient vs control contrasts are excluded.

The reported analysis concerns activations “commonly activated in HFA and controls” (involving a clinical group, high‑functioning autism) rather than a group‑level map from healthy adults only. The inclusion rules require whole‑brain univariate results from a healthy/control sample alone; analyses that involve clinical groups or between‑group comparisons/conjunctions do not meet the sample criterion.

The contrast is a between-group comparison (HFA > Controls) involving a clinical group (high-functioning autism) rather than a whole-brain group map from healthy adults alone. Between-group contrasts and analyses including clinical samples are excluded by the criteria.

Excluded because this is a between-group contrast comparing a clinical group (high-functioning autism) to controls (HFA > Controls) rather than a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone. Additionally, the task probes prosodic/language processing (linguistic/emotional prosody), not affiliation/attachment.

This is a between-group contrast (High-Functioning Autism > Controls) involving a clinical group, not a within-group whole-brain map from healthy adults. The inclusion criteria require group-level whole-brain results from healthy participants (not patient vs control comparisons); thus this analysis must be excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (HFA > Controls) involving a clinical/special group rather than a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone. It therefore fails the sample and exclusion criteria (between-group patient vs control) and does not meet the requirement for a healthy-control task map measuring Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a within-group (controls) whole-brain task-evoked contrast reporting deactivations during a prosodic speech task (linguistic/emotional prosody), which indexes social communication/social processing. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast. (Assuming the control sample are healthy adult participants as implied by the study's design.)

The contrast is from a prosody study (linguistic/emotional prosody) rather than a task that specifically probes affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although the map appears to be a within-controls whole-brain contrast (deactivation), the task domain does not meet the required affiliation/attachment construct, so it should be excluded.

The contrast reflects deactivation in controls during a prosody (linguistic/emotional speech) task. This does not probe Perception and Understanding of the Self (self-awareness, agency, self-knowledge) and so fails the task-domain inclusion criterion. (Whether or not it is a within-group map of controls, the cognitive domain is not self-related.)

This is a within-group (controls) univariate whole-brain task contrast (deactivation in controls) from a prosody task assessing linguistic/emotional prosody — which falls under Reception of Non‑Facial Communication (social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting‑state, or between‑group contrast. (Assumes the control sample are healthy adults as reported in the study.)

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA: brain deactivation) comparing healthy controls to a clinical group (high-functioning autism). Inclusion requires a whole-brain group-level map from healthy adults alone (not a patient vs control comparison). Although the task involves social communication (prosody), the analysis is a group comparison and thus excluded.

This is a within-group (controls) whole-brain activation/deactivation map from a healthy adult control sample, derived from a prosodic speech task that includes emotional prosody. Emotional prosody tasks index perception/understanding of others' emotional states, so the contrast meets the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others construct and does not violate exclusion criteria (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast).

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA) from a study of prosodic speech in autism rather than a within-group whole-brain map of healthy adults. The task probes prosody/emotional prosody, not an affiliation/attachment paradigm, and the presence of a clinical group means it does not meet the healthy-only, within-group inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA), not a within-group healthy adult whole-brain map. The study contrasts healthy controls with a clinical group (HFA) and investigates prosodic speech, not Perception/Understanding of Self tasks, so it fails the sample and task inclusion criteria.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA), i.e. a comparison between healthy controls and a clinical group (high-functioning autism). Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from healthy adults alone (not patient vs control), so this analysis is excluded.

This is a between-group contrast (Controls > HFA: brain deactivation). Inclusion requires a group-level whole-brain map from the healthy/control group alone (within-group/main effect), not a comparison between healthy and clinical groups. Therefore it is excluded.

Although this is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts responses to disfigured vs normal/attractive faces (salience/attention/dehumanization) rather than measuring affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes neural responses to disfigured faces (perception of others) rather than processes involving self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-related judgments. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast of healthy participants' neural responses to faces (disfigured faces before treatment). Viewing and processing faces falls squarely under Reception of Facial Communication, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked fMRI contrast (familywise error corrected) from an fMRI experiment (N=31) probing responses to faces — a canonical social stimulus. The contrast indexes perception/understanding of others (social processing), is not an ROI or connectivity analysis, and is not a between-group comparison. (Note: inclusion assumes the fMRI participants were healthy adult observers as implied by the abstract.)

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked univariate contrast (increased responses to photographs of disfigured faces before treatment) from the fMRI experiment (N=31) and was corrected for multiple comparisons. The task probes social perception/evaluation of others (responses to disfigured faces, linked to biases and dehumanization), which falls under Perception and Understanding of Others (traits/empathy). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, and the participants are healthy adults in the reported fMRI sample.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrast (responses to faces) from an fMRI experiment in healthy adults. Viewing and responding to faces is a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain, group-level task contrast (faces vs baseline) it does not index affiliation/attachment. The task compares responses to disfigured versus typical faces (salience/attractiveness and reduced empathy/dehumanization), not measures of attachment/affiliation (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it fails the domain inclusion criteria.

This contrast reflects neural responses to viewing disfigured faces (perception of others), not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or judgments about the self. Although it appears to be a whole‑brain healthy adult group contrast, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, univariate task contrast (responses to disfigured faces before treatment) in a healthy adult sample, corrected for familywise error. The task measures perception/social evaluation of other people (faces/disfigurement) and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it fits the perception_others inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked contrast in healthy adult participants assessing neural responses to faces (perceptual/receptive processing of facial communication). It is not an ROI or connectivity analysis nor a between-group contrast, and thus meets the Social Communication (reception of facial communication) inclusion criteria.

The contrast (S-performance) comes from a whole-brain group-level fMRI contrast in a task about self–other interactions (cooperation/competition) that probes perception/understanding of the self in a social context. The study used healthy adult participants and the table lists peak coordinates from whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparisons). Therefore it meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The S-performance contrast indexes participants' own performance (self-related monitoring/knowledge) in a cooperation/competition task, matching the Perception and Understanding of Self construct. The table reports whole-brain peak coordinates from a group-level univariate task-evoked contrast in a healthy adult sample, and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast from a cooperation/competition task (social interaction) in a healthy adult sample assessing self/other performance representations. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain contrast (table lists peak coordinates of whole-brain fMRI contrasts) from a study of cooperation and competition in healthy adults. The task (cooperation/competition, social comparison) falls within the affiliation/attachment domain, and the S-performance contrast indexes self-performance representations during social interactions relevant to self–other merging. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast 'O-performance' comes from a whole-brain group-level fMRI table in a study of self–other merging during cooperation/competition in presumably healthy adults. The task explicitly concerns representations of others' performance (social perception/understanding), and the result is reported as whole-brain peaks rather than an ROI or connectivity analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The analysis is labeled "S-performance" (self-performance). Although the study used healthy adults and reports whole-brain task contrasts (so it meets sample and whole-brain requirements), this contrast indexes one's own performance rather than perception/understanding of others (the annotation requires contrasts that measure others' states/abilities, e.g., cooperation/competition contrasts targeting other-related representations). Therefore it does not meet the "perception_others" construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from a healthy adult sample probing cooperation/competition and self–other merging (tracking others' performance), which fits the affiliation/attachment domain (social interaction, social comparison). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

The contrast (O-performance) comes from a whole-brain group-level fMRI contrast reported in a healthy adult sample studying cooperation/competition and self–other merging (social comparison). This fits the Social Communication domain (cooperation/competition) and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

The contrast labeled "O-performance" comes from a whole-brain group-level task fMRI analysis in a study of cooperation/competition and self–other estimation. The task directly measures representations of others' performance/ability (fits Perception and Understanding of Others; cooperation/competition and social comparison are listed examples). The table reports whole-brain peak coordinates (not an ROI or connectivity analysis) and the study concerns healthy adult behavior, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast labeled 'O-performance' pertains to tracking others' performance (other-related processing), not judgments or self-representation. Although the task (cooperation/competition) and analysis are whole-brain in healthy adults, the contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as required by the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (genetic > non-genetic) derived from a task-based movie-watching paradigm about a moral/social dilemma between sisters in healthy adult participants. The effect indexes social cognition (differential processing of kinship), and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical comparison — therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a movie-based kinship/moral-dilemma task in healthy adults. It targets kinship-related social processing (an example Social Communication task) and is not an ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from healthy adult participants, probing kinship-related social perception during a movie task. It measures perception/understanding of others (kinship/moral scenario) and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample, within-subject whole-brain voxelwise contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from a task explicitly manipulating kinship (affiliation/attachment). Although the metric is inter-subject correlation, the result is reported as voxelwise t-maps/clusters (not an ROI or seed-based connectivity or between-group clinical comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for an affiliation/attachment task contrast.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (genetic > non-genetic) from healthy adult participants during a kinship-related movie task. The task is a kinship-related social scenario (explicitly listed as an example for the Perception and Understanding of Self construct). The analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or a between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion and not the exclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain, voxelwise contrast from a task-based (movie watching) experiment in healthy adults that probes social processing (responses to perceived kinship). Although the measure uses inter-subject correlations, the result is a group-level voxelwise task-evoked contrast (non-genetic > genetic), not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast from a movie-watching task in healthy adult participants comparing viewing of genetic vs non-genetic sisters (a kinship-related social scenario). The contrast probes social/kinship communication (non-genetic > genetic) and is not an ROI, seed-based, resting-state, or between-group patient comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast from a movie task manipulating perceived kinship (genetic vs non-genetic sisters), which directly probes kinship-related affiliation/attachment. It is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise contrast from a healthy adult sample on a movie task manipulating perceived kinship (genetic vs non-genetic sisters). The contrast (non-genetic > genetic) probes kinship-related social perception, which fits the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct (example: kinship-related scenarios). Although the metric is inter-subject correlation rather than a conventional GLM, it yields whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (t-values) at the group level and is not an ROI/seed, resting‑state, or between-group clinical comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast from a healthy adult sample comparing movie-viewing conditions that manipulate kinship (genetic vs non-genetic sisters). The contrast indexes perception/understanding of others in a social/kinship moral scenario and is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise contrast (clusters with peak coordinates and t-values) from a task that probes moral/kinship social cognition (moral dilemma viewing/decision). The subjects are healthy adults and the analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or a patient vs. control comparison. The contrast reflects social processing (mentalizing, moral/emotional evaluation), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast from a moral-dilemma task manipulating kinship (genetic vs. adopted sisters), which directly probes kinship-related affiliation/attachment. The table reports cluster sizes, peak coordinates and t-values (i.e., a voxelwise task-evoked contrast) in a healthy adult sample, and is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group patient comparison.

Although the task involves kinship/moral scenarios (relevant to perception_self), the reported analysis is an inter-subject correlation comparison (ISC) across conditions rather than a group-level univariate, task-evoked voxelwise GLM contrast. ISC is a connectivity/synchrony measure and therefore does not meet the requirement for a whole-brain univariate task-evoked statistical map.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise comparison of brain responses to kinship-related moral scenarios (genetic vs. adopted sisters) in healthy adults. The task maps social communication (kinship/moral dilemma) and the reported clusters are group-level voxelwise statistics (t values). The analysis is not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, resting-state, or a patient vs control contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional > neutral) from an emotional prosody comprehension task, which measures social processing (perception/understanding of others' emotions / social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and the study context indicates a healthy adult sample, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise comparison of viewing conditions in healthy adults (belief that sisters are genetic vs. adoptive) addressing kinship-related social scenarios — a Perception and Understanding of Others task. Although the metric is inter-subject correlation (ISC), the paper reports voxelwise t-maps/clusters for the condition contrast (genetic > non-genetic), so it is a task-evoked, group-level whole-brain analysis (not an ROI, seed-based connectivity, or between-group clinical contrast) and meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast indexes emotional prosody (simple/complex emotion vs neutral) rather than an affiliation/attachment task (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional prosody trials > neutral) reported with corrected p-values and MNI coordinates from a healthy adult sample. The task measures reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody), and the analysis is not ROI-based, connectivity, or a between-group contrast—therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional prosody vs neutral) indexing perception/understanding of others' emotional states in a healthy sample (no ROI or connectivity or between-group comparison), so it meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotion) reporting voxelwise local maxima (MNI) at corrected threshold, from an emotional prosody task that probes emotion recognition/social communication. The sample and contrast are consistent with healthy adult social processing (perception/understanding of others), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

The contrast indexes emotional prosody comprehension (perception of others' emotions) vs neutral, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or other self-referential judgments. Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self and thus does not meet the annotation criteria.

This contrast (complex vs. simple emotional prosody) probes general emotion processing/mental-state attribution, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved-one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation, bonding). Although likely a whole-brain, healthy-group contrast, the task does not measure affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the domain inclusion criterion.

Although this is a healthy adult, whole-brain group-level contrast, the task contrasts comprehension of others' emotional prosody (complex vs simple emotion) and therefore indexes perception/understanding of others' emotional states, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or self-related judgment. It does not meet the construct requirement for Perception and Understanding of Self.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex vs simple emotional prosody) indexing perception/understanding of others' emotional states (emotional prosody comprehension). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody) in a healthy adult sample, measuring reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

This contrast examines emotional prosody (complex vs simple emotions) and does not target affiliation/attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although it appears to be a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task domain (emotion recognition/prosody) does not meet the required affiliation/attachment criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise contrast comparing complex vs. simple emotional prosody (socially relevant emotion perception/understanding of others), reported as whole-brain local maxima in MNI space and thresholded (p<0.05 corrected). It is a task-evoked, within-group/univariate comparison (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast) and therefore meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

This contrast indexes emotional prosody comprehension (complex vs. simple emotions in others' voices) rather than processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it appears to be a whole-brain, within-group task contrast (likely in healthy adults), the task measures perception/understanding of others' emotions, not the participant's self-related processing, so it does not meet the "perception_self" construct.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (complex > simple emotional prosody) indexing reception of non-facial social communication (emotional prosody/affect recognition). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and—given the study aims and description—comes from healthy adult participants, so it meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast in healthy adults (complex > simple emotional prosody, pitch controlled) measuring comprehension of others' emotions from vocal cues — a Perception/Understanding of Others (understanding mental states) task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-subject, group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (anticipation of an animate [human] target vs inanimate target) in healthy adult volunteers, directly indexing a social-processing task (anticipation of touching a human hand vs a mannequin). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state-only, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample and a group-level whole-brain task contrast (anticipation of an animate human hand vs inanimate mannequin hand). The task indexes sensitivity to social/animate targets (social interaction/approach), which fits the affiliation/attachment domain (detection of and attention to social cues). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

Healthy adult sample and a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (anticipation of animate target vs inanimate target). The task probes anticipation of social touch/interaction (human hand vs mannequin), which falls under non‑facial social communication (production/reception of socially relevant tactile interaction). The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or a between-group contrast.

Healthy adult sample; group-level, whole-brain task contrast (anticipation of animate vs inanimate target) — a direct measure of animacy perception/action perception (Perception and Understanding of Others). Not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target) probes social/approach sensitivity to animate agents rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency/self-monitoring. It does not target judgments or representations of the self, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrast in healthy adults (anticipation of a human/animate target vs baseline). The task probes sensitivity to a social/animate target (social cue/approach behavior), fitting the affiliation/attachment construct (detection/attention to social cues and predisposition for social interaction). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis; inclusion of a narcissism covariate does not disqualify it.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group task contrast in healthy adults (anticipation of touching an animate vs. inanimate target), the task probes social interaction/approach to an animate object rather than the exchange or processing of socially communicative signals (receptive/expressive facial or non‑facial communication). The annotation target is specifically Social Communication (reception/production of social signals), so this contrast does not meet that construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast in healthy adult participants (anticipation of touching an animate vs baseline), which probes social processing (anticipation of interacting with a human hand). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain task contrast in a healthy sample, the contrast indexes anticipation of touching an animate versus inanimate target (a social/approach process) rather than processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or agency. The task does not probe judgments or awareness about the self, so it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adult volunteers comparing anticipation of an animate (human) target versus baseline (with narcissism covariate). The contrast indexes animacy/social perception (animacy perception subconstruct) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group/resting-state analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This analysis is a conjunction of a task contrast (anticipation of an animate target) with a resting-state measure (PLE). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked map; the exclusion criteria disallow resting-state analyses (e.g., PLE). Because the reported contrast explicitly involves resting-state PLE, it does not meet the ‘whole-brain task-only’ requirement.

Although the task contrast (anticipation of touching an animate target) involves social interaction in healthy adults and is whole-brain, this specific analysis is a conjunction that includes a resting-state metric (PLE). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain map alone; the presence of resting-state analysis/contrast (PLE) in the conjunction meets the exclusion criterion for resting-state analyses, so it should be excluded.

This analysis is a conjunction of a task contrast (anticipation of an animate target) with a resting-state measure (PLE). The annotation requires group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked maps that probe perception/understanding of the self. This conjunction involves a resting-state analysis (PLE), which is explicitly excluded, and the task contrast probes social/animate perception rather than clear self-related processes (agency or self-knowledge). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria for perception_self.

Although the study used healthy adults and a social touch anticipation task, this specific analysis is a conjunction/interaction that includes resting-state PLE measures (Resting state PLE vs. baseline ∩ task contrast). The inclusion criteria require a group-level, univariate whole-brain task-evoked map alone; analyses that involve resting-state metrics are excluded. Therefore this analysis should not be included.

The FT>FA contrast indexes perception of stimulus direction/potential social involvement (facing toward vs away) using biological motion stimuli, not measures of affiliation/attachment such as close relationships, kinship, cooperation, or attachment styles. Although participants judge social involvement, the task does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs required by the inclusion criteria.

The FT>FA contrast tests perception of others' facing direction (facing towards vs away), a socially relevant non‑facial communicative cue (reception of non‑facial communication). The study reports group-level task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults (whole-brain univariate analyses rather than ROI or connectivity), so it meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

FT > FA is a within-group task contrast (facing-toward vs facing-away) from a healthy adult sample performing a social judgment task (direction/social involvement of biological motion). This is a univariate task-evoked contrast reporting whole-brain activation (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), and it directly indexes social processing, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the task contrast (anticipation of an animate vs inanimate target) indexes animacy perception (fits perception_others), this specific analysis is a conjunction that includes a resting-state metric (PLE) and covariate (PNI-NG). The annotation criteria exclude resting-state/PLE analyses and require a pure task-evoked whole-brain group map. Because this analysis combines task and resting-state measures, it should be excluded.

FT > FA is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (facing-toward vs facing-away) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (judging others' direction/intent), is a whole-brain univariate result and not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — therefore it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The FA>FT contrast indexes stimulus direction (facing away vs toward) during biological-motion perception, not an affiliation/attachment task or contrast (e.g., loved one vs stranger, kinship, cooperation). Although social involvement is discussed, the task does not measure attachment or affiliation constructs, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

The FT>FA contrast indexes perception of others' stimulus direction (facing toward vs away) and social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency, or judgments about one's own traits/states. Although the study used healthy adults and a whole-brain univariate contrast, the task measures perception of others' orientation relative to the observer rather than Perception/Understanding of the Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

FA > FT is a within-group task contrast from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological motion (direction/facing), a social-processing task (social involvement cues). It is a univariate task-evoked group contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

FA>FT is a group-level task contrast from an fMRI study in healthy adults testing perception of body/biological motion direction (facing toward vs away), which indexes reception of non‑facial social communication/intent. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL > PLD) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (judging facing direction), which targets social processing (understanding social cues/intentions). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (HL > PLD) comes from a biological-motion / stimulus-direction task (judging whether walkers face toward/away) probing perceptual/social-cognitive processing (mirror/mentalizing systems), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although social content is present, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

FA>FT contrasts direction of observed biological motion (facing away vs toward the observer) and indexes perception of others' motion/social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, self-monitoring, or self-knowledge. Although the sample appears to be healthy adults and the contrast is likely a whole-brain group contrast, the task does not measure Perception and Understanding of the Self as defined by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

FA > FT is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (facing-away vs facing-toward) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of others' actions/intentions (PLDs and human-like walkers). It is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis and maps onto the Perception/Understanding of Others construct (action/animacy perception).

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (HL > PLD) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological motion/animacy and social meaning (Perception and Understanding of Others—action/animacy perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (HL > PLD) in healthy adult participants, not an ROI/seed/connectivity or between-group analysis. The task probes perception of biological motion/body orientation (facing toward/away) and the stimulus' potential for social involvement, which falls under reception of non‑facial social communication (receptive non‑facial cues). Therefore it meets the sample, analysis type, and construct criteria.

The contrast (HL > PLD) contrasts types of observed stimuli (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) while participants judged stimulus direction (facing toward/away). This probes perception of others and stimulus social potential, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency or explicit self-related judgments required for the "perception_self" construct. Although the task references whether stimuli face the participant, it does not measure self-related cognition as defined by the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level univariate contrast (PLD > HL) on healthy adult participants using a task that probes perception/interpretation of biological motion and social intentions. It is a whole-brain task-evoked analysis targeting social processing (perception/understanding of others), so it meets the inclusion criteria and does not fall under any exclusions.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task (judging direction of point-light displays vs human-like walkers) probes biological motion and social perception, not affiliation/attachment (e.g., bonding, kinship, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). The contrast PLD > HL does not measure affiliation or attachment, so it does not meet the annotation inclusion criteria.

PLD > HL is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing types of biological motion (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) in healthy adult participants, indexing action/animacy perception (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The PLD > HL contrast compares stimulus types (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) and reflects perception of others' biological motion/direction, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although the task references facing toward/away from the observer, it does not probe judgments about the self (e.g., self vs other, social comparison, kinship), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criteria.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain contrast on healthy adults, PLD > HL contrasts stimulus type (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) during a direction judgment task and primarily indexes biological-motion/visual processing differences rather than an exchange or explicit measure of social communication. The contrast does not directly measure social-communication behavior (reception/production of communicative signals) as required by the annotation criteria, so it should be excluded.

The task (judging direction of point-light displays / human-like walkers) probes biological motion and social involvement potential, not affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, bonding, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain group fMRI analysis in healthy adults, the contrast does not measure affiliation or attachment per the inclusion criteria.

The STIMULUS*DIRECTION contrast tests perception of social motion (PLDs and human-like walkers facing toward/away), a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). The study reports group-level task-evoked fMRI activation differences (not ROI or connectivity, nor a patient vs control comparison), so it meets the sample, whole-brain, and task-related inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

The contrast (STIMULUS*DIRECTION) is a group-level, task-evoked whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis in healthy adults and tests perception of social orientation/intent (facing toward vs away) from biological motion — i.e., reception of non-facial social communication. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The task (judging point-light displays / human-like walkers as facing toward/away) probes biological motion and social orientation/potential for social involvement, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., close relationships, kinship, cooperation, attachment styles). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific inclusion criterion despite being a healthy adult fMRI group analysis.

The STIMULUS*DIRECTION contrast indexes perception of others' motion/orientation (facing toward vs away) and neural coding of stimulus direction/social involvement, not processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge or agency. Although healthy group and whole‑brain, the task measures perception of others relative to the observer rather than Perception and Understanding of the Self as defined, so it does not meet the construct criteria.

The analysis reports group-level task-evoked contrasts on healthy adult participants performing a social-perception task (judging facing direction of point-light/human-like walkers), targeting social processing (perception/understanding of others). Nothing indicates this was an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, and the description implies whole-brain univariate activation differences (MNS vs MS). Thus it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level task fMRI contrast (STIMULUS × DIRECTION) in healthy adults probing perception of others (animacy/action perception—PLD vs human-like walkers facing toward/away). It is a within-subject whole-brain univariate task contrast (not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast in healthy adult participants probing perception of biological/social motion (point-light displays and human-like walkers), which maps onto perception/understanding of others (action/animacy perception). The reported effects are univariate whole-brain group results (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a group-level task fMRI contrast in healthy adult participants probing perception of others' facing direction (PLD and human-like walkers) — a form of receptive, non‑facial social communication (inferring social involvement/intent). It is not described as an ROI or connectivity analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although the study used healthy participants and likely reports whole-brain group contrasts, the task contrasts concern perception of stimulus direction (facing toward vs away) and stimulus type (PLD vs HL) — i.e., coding social involvement of observed agents — rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Therefore this analysis does not meet the ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (FT_PLD > HL) from a healthy adult sample probing perception/interpretation of biological motion and social intent (social processing). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

FT_PLD > HL is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing point-light displays (PLD) to human-like walkers (HL) in healthy adult participants, indexing perception of others (action/animacy perception). It is a standard whole-brain univariate fMRI contrast (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

The contrast (FT_PLD > HL) comes from a biological-motion / direction-discrimination task (point-light displays vs human-like walkers) probing perceptual coding and social involvement, not measures of affiliation, attachment, close relationships, or bonding. Although healthy adult group-level fMRI, the task/contrast does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain fMRI contrast in healthy adults that indexes perception of social intent/body orientation from point-light displays versus human-like walkers. The task involves receptive, non-facial social communication (inferring social involvement/direction from biological motion), and is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

The contrast (FT_PLD > HL) indexes perception of stimulus direction / potential social involvement of others (point-light displays vs human-like walkers facing the observer), not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although it is a group-level fMRI contrast in healthy adults, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self as defined by the annotation criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (FT_HL > PLD) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological/social motion (judging facing direction of human-like walkers vs point-light displays). It targets social processing (perception/understanding of others) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The contrast (human-like walkers vs point-light displays; judging facing direction) probes biological motion / social intent detection, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Although likely a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, it does not meet the requirement that the task/contrast assess affiliation and attachment.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (HL vs PLD for facing-toward stimuli) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of social directionality/intent (potential for social involvement). This indexes reception of non-facial social communication cues (body/orientation), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, and thus meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL vs PLD; FT likely = facing-toward) from a healthy adult sample probing biological/social motion perception and inferred social intentions (action/animacy perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and thus meets the whole-brain Perception_and_Understanding_of_Others inclusion criteria.

The contrast FT_HL > PLD compares stimulus types (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) and indexes perceptual coding of stimulus direction/social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, agency, or self-knowledge. Although the task referenced the observer (facing toward/away), the contrast does not measure Perception/Understanding of the Self (e.g., self-related judgments or social comparison), so it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast comparing point-light displays (PLD) to human-like walkers during a social perception task (judging facing/toward vs away). Participants are healthy adults and the contrast probes social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level univariate contrast on healthy adults, the task (judging facing direction of point-light displays vs human-like walkers; assessing potential for social involvement/biological motion) does not target affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content inclusion criteria for "affiliation_attachment."

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast in healthy adults comparing point-light displays (PLD) to human-like walkers (HL) during a direction/social-intention judgment task (Perception/Action/Animacy). It is a univariate task contrast (FA_PLD > HL), not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and therefore fits the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (PLD vs HL) in healthy adults indexing perception of socially relevant biological motion (direction/facing, i.e., reception of non‑facial social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

Although this is a healthy-group, whole-brain task contrast, the task contrasts perception of others' biological motion/stimulus type (PLD vs HL) and coding of stimulus direction (facing toward/away). This probes social perception and potential for social involvement with an observed agent, not processes of self-awareness, self-judgment, agency or self-knowledge. Therefore it does not meet the 'Perception and Understanding of Self' construct.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults comparing human-like walkers (HL) to point-light displays (PLD) during a task judging facing direction — a social-perception task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the task probes perception of biological motion/direction (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) and social involvement potential, not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation, loved one vs stranger). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain fMRI contrast (human-like walkers vs point-light displays) in healthy adults assessing perception of social orientation/potential for social involvement from biological motion. That maps onto Reception of Non-Facial Communication (a form of social communication) and does not fall into the exclusion categories (ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast).

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (HL > PLD) from an fMRI study of healthy adults probing perception of biological motion/social involvement (action/animacy perception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore fits the 'perception_others' inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group task-evoked univariate contrast (PLD_FT > FA) from a healthy adult sample assessing perception of the social direction/intent (point-light displays facing toward vs away). The task targets social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the study uses healthy adults and the contrast appears to be a group-level whole-brain task contrast (HL vs PLD facing direction), the task indexes perception of others' biological motion and social involvement (whether walkers face toward/away) rather than processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or explicit judgments about the self. Therefore it does not meet the construct requirements for Perception and Understanding of Self.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults, the task probes perception of biological motion and stimulus directionality (PLD vs human-like walkers; facing toward/away) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close-relationship, parental/peer bonding, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

Although the contrast (PLD facing-toward > facing-away) is a whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults and probes social involvement, it does not measure self-related processes (self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency or self-evaluation). The task judges stimulus direction relative to the observer rather than accessing or judging the participant's own traits/states, so it does not meet the Perception_and_Understanding_of_Self construct.

The contrast (PLD facing-toward > facing-away) is a group-level task-evoked fMRI contrast in a healthy adult sample probing perception of body-orientation/social directedness (non-facial social cue). This maps onto 'reception of non-facial communication' and is not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-subject, group-level univariate contrast (PLD facing-away > facing-toward) from a task probing social perception (direction/potential for social involvement) in healthy adults. It is whole-brain task-evoked fMRI and not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast in healthy adults comparing point-light displays (PLD) facing toward vs away (PLD_FT > FA). The task probes perception/understanding of others (biological motion/animacy/action perception), and the contrast indexes social orientation/intent—a fit to the perception_others construct. It is not a ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults, the task contrasts biological motion direction (PLD facing away vs toward) rather than any measure of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task-based inclusion criteria for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

This is a within-group, task-evoked univariate contrast (PLD facing away > facing toward) from healthy adult participants probing perception of social orientation/body language (reception of non‑facial social communication). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

PLD_FA > FT is a within-group, task-evoked contrast comparing point-light displays facing away vs toward, indexing perception of biological motion/social orientation (action/animacy perception). The study used healthy adult participants and reports group-level fMRI contrasts (not ROI, connectivity, or between-group), so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (human-like walkers facing toward vs away) in a healthy adult sample that probes perception of others and potential for social involvement. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the whole-brain social-processing inclusion criteria.

PLD_FA > FT contrasts stimulus direction (point-light displays facing away vs toward the observer) — a perceptual/social-directionality manipulation of others’ biological motion. Although it references potential for social involvement, it does not measure self-related processing, self-awareness, self-knowledge, or judgments about the participant (the self). Thus it does not meet the annotation's Perception and Understanding of Self criterion.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (human-like walkers facing toward > facing away) from a healthy adult sample probing perception of biological motion/social involvement. It is a univariate task contrast assessing perception/understanding of others (animacy/action/social direction), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis — therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast on healthy adults (human-like walkers facing toward vs away), the task probes low-level social perception (direction/potential for social involvement/biological motion) rather than measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the rubric requirement that the task/contrast specifically assesses affiliation/attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain fMRI contrast (HL facing toward > facing away) in healthy adults and not an ROI/ connectivity or between-group analysis. The task indexes perception of social intent/directionality of a human walker (a non‑facial social communicative cue), fitting the 'reception of non‑facial communication' subconstruct of Social Communication.

Although this is a whole-brain group contrast in healthy adults (HL facing-toward > facing-away), the task contrasts perception of another agent's orientation/social involvement rather than processes of self‑awareness, self‑knowledge, or judgments about the self. The contrast indexes social/perceptual processing of others (potential for social involvement), not the Perception and Understanding of Self construct, so it should be excluded.

This is a group-level, task-evoked univariate whole-brain contrast (HL facing away > facing toward) from a study in healthy adults performing a social perception task (judging walker orientation). It targets perception/understanding of others (social processing), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

Although this is a group-level whole-brain task contrast in healthy adults, the task contrasts perception of human-like walkers facing toward/away (social directionality/potential for social involvement). It does not assess affiliation or attachment constructs (e.g., close relationships, kinship, parenting, cooperation/competition, attachment style), so it does not meet the domain requirement for "affiliation_attachment."

The contrast (HL facing away > facing toward) reflects perception of others' direction/social involvement, not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge, or agency. Although it involves the observer, it indexes social/perceptual coding of external stimuli rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, so it does not meet the construct inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked fMRI contrast (HL facing away > HL facing toward) in a study of healthy adults judging walker facing-direction. The task probes inference of social intentions from body motion (reception of non‑facial social communication), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison — therefore it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (HL facing away > facing toward) from a study of healthy adults performing judgments about the social orientation of human-like walkers/point-light displays. The contrast measures perception/understanding of others (social direction/intent), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a whole-brain, group-level (voxelwise) task-evoked analysis (whole-brain MLM) from a social evaluation task involving healthy adult participants. The contrast measures social processing (evaluative judgments of people) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although the analysis is a healthy adult, group-level whole-brain task contrast, the task probes social evaluations of other people (judgments about targets with positive/negative/ambivalent information), not processes of self-perception, self-knowledge, or self-related judgments. Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' construct.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis likely on healthy adults, the task and contrast index general social evaluation under conflict (negative vs positive judgments) rather than measures of affiliation/attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation/bonding). Therefore it does not meet the content requirement for the "affiliation_attachment" category.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical analysis (whole-brain MLM) in a healthy adult sample probing social evaluations of other people (judgments of targets based on trait information). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group contrast, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for Perception and Understanding of Others.

This is a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked (voxelwise) analysis in a healthy adult sample (interaction of trial type and response behavior), not an ROI or connectivity/resting-state analysis. The task probes social evaluations of person information (processing/reception of socially relevant information), which fits the Social Communication domain (reception/processing of social information), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (table title/description: 'Results of the ROI analyses'), which fails the requirement for a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. In addition, the task concerns face specialization rather than an affiliation/attachment paradigm. Therefore it should be excluded.

This is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (table: 'Regions of interest' / 'Results of the ROI analyses'), not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. The inclusion criteria require univariate whole-brain analyses; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

Excluded because this is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (the table and description explicitly report ROI results). The annotation requires group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked maps; ROI analyses are listed as exclusion criteria. Additionally, the task concerns face specialization rather than Perception/Understanding of the Self.

This analysis is an ROI analysis (table: 'Regions of interest; Results of the ROI analyses'), which violates the inclusion requirement for group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise maps. Therefore it should be excluded despite involving face processing.

This is an ROI analysis (table/analysis explicitly reports ROI results), which fails the requirement for a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. Although the task involves face processing in adults, ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) in 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathy/social task (rating others' emotional intensity). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing (perception/understanding of others' emotions), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) in 34 healthy adults. The task requires participants to watch people talking about autobiographical events and rate the narrator's emotional intensity — i.e., reception/recognition of affective social signals (reception of facial/non‑facial communication), which fits the Social Communication construct. The analysis is not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast.

Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level comparison in healthy adults, the task probes empathic/emotional processing (emotional > neutral video clips) rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, cooperation). It does not target measures of attachment or social-bonding/affiliation constructs, so it fails the requirement that the task/contrast measure affiliation and attachment.

Healthy adult sample (n=34) with a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) probing perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathic accuracy task). Not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

The contrast (emotional > neutral video clips) indexes empathic processing / perception of others' emotions (empathic accuracy task), not self-related processes. The annotation requires measures of perception/understanding of the self (e.g., self-awareness, self-knowledge, agency), so this analysis does not meet the construct and should be excluded.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (neutral > emotional) from 34 healthy adult participants performing an empathic accuracy task—clearly a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level contrast in healthy adults, the task is an empathic-accuracy paradigm contrasting emotional versus neutral video clips. The contrast measures general emotional/empathy processing, not affiliation or attachment (e.g., loved‑one vs stranger, kinship, parental/peer bonding, cooperation) as required by the inclusion criteria. Therefore it does not meet the "affiliation_attachment" task requirement.

Although this is a group-level, whole-brain contrast in healthy adults, the contrast (neutral > emotional video clips) indexes processing of others' emotional videos in an empathic-accuracy task (perception of the narrator), not perception/understanding of the self.
