Therefore it does not meet the 'perception_self' domain criteria.

This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (neutral > emotional) from 34 healthy adults performing an empathic-accuracy task that involves watching/listening to people tell autobiographical stories. The task indexes reception of non-facial social communication (emotion tracking/affect recognition). The contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for the social_communication annotation.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants from an empathic-accuracy task (watching others' autobiographical emotional/neutral videos). It assesses perception/understanding of others' emotional states (understanding mental states), and does not involve ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparisons.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in a sample of healthy adults (N=34) showing brain activation positively related to Z-transformed empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) scores during an empathic-accuracy task (viewing/rating emotional video clips). The task measures social processing (empathy/perception of others), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate fMRI analysis in healthy adults (n=34) relating brain activity to z-scored empathic accuracy (Z-EA) during an empathic accuracy task (watching and rating others' emotional videos). The task measures reception of social/non‑facial communicative cues (emotional tracking), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level task analysis on healthy adults, the contrast/measure (activation positively related to Z-transformed empathic-accuracy scores during emotional video clips) indexes empathy/empathic tracking rather than affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close‑relationship, cooperation/competition). It does not test affiliation/attachment constructs or contrasts (e.g., loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the affiliation_attachment inclusion criteria.

The contrast 'Positively related to Z-EA scores' indexes empathic accuracy (tracking others' emotions) — a measure of perception/understanding of others (cognitive empathy), not perception or understanding of the self. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy-group analysis, it does not probe self-related processes, so it does not meet the 'perception_self' inclusion criterion.

This is a group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analysis in a sample of healthy adults (N=34) linking empathic accuracy (Z-EA) to task-evoked activation while watching others' emotional videos. The contrast reflects perception/understanding of others (empathic accuracy/cognitive empathy), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

Although this is a whole-brain, group-level analysis on healthy adult participants, the contrast/measure (brain activity related to empathic accuracy — “Z-EA scores” — and emotional vs neutral video clips) probes empathy/empathic tracking, not affiliation or attachment. The task does not target affiliation/attachment constructs (e.g., kinship, loved one vs stranger, cooperation), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for the affiliation_attachment annotation.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in a sample of healthy adults using an empathic-accuracy task (social processing). The contrast reports voxels whose activity is negatively related to Z-transformed empathic-accuracy scores (a within-group brain–behavior regression), not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The analysis is a group-level, voxelwise correlation of task-evoked activation with Z-transformed empathic-accuracy (Z-EA) scores in a sample of healthy adults watching autobiographical emotional video clips. The task measures reception of socially relevant, non-facial communication (tracking others' emotions), and the analysis is whole-brain and univariate (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group contrast), so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

This analysis indexes neural correlates of empathic accuracy (tracking others' emotions) — a between-subject regression of brain activity with Z-EA scores — from an other-focused empathy task. The construct 'perception_self' requires processes of self-awareness/knowledge or contrasts probing self-related perception. Although it is a whole-brain group-level map in healthy adults, the contrast measures perception of others (empathic accuracy), not perception/understanding of the self, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults correlating brain activity with participants' moment-to-moment ratings of another person's emotional intensity (an empathic accuracy / perception-of-others task). It measures social processing (perception/understanding of others' emotions) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analysis in healthy adults relating task-evoked activity during an empathic-accuracy (video-rating) task to individual Z-scored EA scores. The task measures perception/understanding of others' emotional states, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This analysis measures moment-to-moment tracking of a narrator's emotional intensity (empathic accuracy/empathy), not affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, loved‑one vs stranger, bonding, parental/peer attachment). Although it is a whole‑brain, group‑level contrast in healthy adults, the task does not assess affiliation/attachment constructs, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Healthy adult sample (n=34) and the reported result is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise effect (significant clusters, TFCE pFWE<0.05). The contrast/analysis indexes participants' tracking of another person's emotional intensity (perception/understanding of others' emotional state), and it is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis. Therefore it meets the "perception_others" inclusion criteria.

The analysis indexes participants' tracking of the narrator's emotional intensity (empathic accuracy) — i.e., perception of another person's emotions — not processes of self-perception or self-knowledge. Although it is a whole-brain, healthy adult, task-evoked group analysis, it does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

The analysis is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adults relating brain activity to participants' continuous ratings of others' emotional intensity during an empathy task. This measures perception/understanding of others (social processing), and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

Although the analysis is a whole-brain, group-level task contrast in a healthy adult sample, the task and contrast probe empathic tracking of others' emotional intensity (empathy/cognitive and affective empathy), not affiliation or attachment processes (e.g., kinship, loved-one vs stranger, bonding or close-relationship measures). Therefore it does not meet the domain-specific task/contrast requirement for affiliation_attachment.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adults relating neural activity to continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity. The task measures reception of socially relevant emotional information (receptive social communication), not an ROI or connectivity or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for social_communication.

The contrast indexes participants' tracking of the narrator's emotional intensity (empathic accuracy / perception of others), not processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or agency. Although it is a whole‑brain, within‑group analysis on healthy adults, the content does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise task contrast (deception > cooperation) in healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind / social interaction task. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate analysis in healthy adult participants examining brain activity correlated (negatively) with participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity — i.e., perception/understanding of others' emotional states (empathy task). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets the inclusion criteria for perception_others.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise univariate analysis in healthy adults linking BOLD to participants' continuous ratings of a narrator's emotional intensity during autobiographical video clips. The task measures reception of socially relevant affective information (empathic/affect recognition), not an ROI or connectivity or a between-group contrast, so it meets the social_communication inclusion criteria.

Although this is a whole-brain, within-group contrast in healthy adults from a task that includes cooperation, the specific contrast (DEC>COOP) isolates deception-related processing (deception greater than cooperation). It does not directly index affiliation/attachment (e.g., cooperation > control or loved one > stranger) and therefore does not meet the requirement that the contrast measure Affiliation and Attachment.

DEC>COOP is a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast from healthy adult participants performing a ToM task contrasting deception vs cooperation. The task involves social interaction scenarios (cooperation/deception), which fits the Social Communication construct (cooperation tasks/social scenarios). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (DEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants on a theory-of-mind task contrasting deception versus cooperation, which directly probes understanding of others’ mental states. It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

The DEC>COOP contrast reflects participants' reasoning about other protagonists' intentions/expectations (theory-of-mind about others — deception vs cooperation), not self-referential processes. Although the sample and analysis appear to be a healthy group whole-brain contrast, the contrast does not measure Perception and Understanding of Self (self-awareness/agency/self-knowledge), so it should be excluded.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (deception vs cooperation/deception) from a ToM/social task in healthy adult participants. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis and directly measures social processing (theory of mind), so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, task-evoked whole-brain contrast (DEC>COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants reflecting cooperative/deceptive social interactions. The task directly measures social communication (cooperation/deception), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

Although the study used healthy adults and reports a whole-brain group contrast (satisfying sample and whole‑brain criteria), the DEC>COOPDEC contrast indexes reasoning about other characters' intentions/expectations (theory-of-mind about others: deception vs combined cooperation/deception). The perception_self construct targets processes of self-awareness, self-knowledge or judgments about the self (agency/self‑monitoring). This contrast reflects other‑focused ToM/social cognition rather than Perception and Understanding of Self, so it should be excluded.

Although the study used a healthy adult sample and reports whole-brain task contrasts, the specific contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) isolates deception-related processes rather than affiliation/attachment. The contrast does not directly measure affiliation (e.g., cooperation vs non-affiliation or loved one vs stranger), so it does not meet the requirement that the contrast index affiliation/attachment.

This is a within-group, voxelwise whole-brain contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) from healthy adult participants performing a Theory-of-Mind/social task (cooperation/deception). It is a task-evoked univariate group contrast measuring social processing and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (DEC > COOPDEC) in healthy adult participants from a theory-of-mind task probing others' intentions/expectations — i.e., understanding others' mental states — and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, whole-brain voxelwise contrast (COOPDEC > DEC) from healthy adult participants in a task explicitly probing cooperation/deception (social interaction/ToM). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and matches the Social Communication construct (cooperation).

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate task contrast (COOPDEC > DEC) from healthy adult participants performing a theory-of-mind task about others' intentions (cooperation/deception), which falls squarely under Perception and Understanding of Others (understanding mental states). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group comparison.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast from healthy adult volunteers (study reports healthy volunteers, n=13, with voxelwise thresholds), and the task directly probes cooperation/deception social interactions. The COOPDEC>DEC contrast isolates the cooperation component (affiliative interaction) relative to deception, which fits the affiliation/attachment domain (cooperation as positive social bonding). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a whole-brain, group-level within-subject contrast (COOPDEC>DEC) reported in healthy adult volunteers (n=13) from a ToM task involving cooperation/deception. The task falls under the example tasks listed for Perception and Understanding of Self (cooperation/competition), and the contrast is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants in a theory-of-mind (cooperation/deception) task. It directly probes social processing (understanding others' intentions/expectations), is not an ROI or connectivity or between-group analysis, and therefore meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) from healthy adult participants on a ToM task that explicitly probes cooperation/deception—paradigms listed under Social Communication (e.g., cooperation). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate contrast in healthy adult participants (COOPDEC>COOP) from a task that explicitly manipulates cooperation (an affiliation-related social behavior). The contrast compares cooperative/deceptive interactions to cooperation alone, which falls under the ‘cooperation and competition’ type tasks used to index affiliation/attachment processes. It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis.

This is a within-group, task-evoked contrast (COOPDEC > COOP) from healthy adult participants in a theory-of-mind (cooperation/deception) task. The table reports voxelwise thresholds (p and cluster extent), indicating a whole-brain univariate analysis, and the contrast probes understanding of others' intentions/mental states (Perception and Understanding of Others). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis.

This is a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) within-subject contrast (COOPDEC>COOP) in healthy adult participants from a ToM task that includes cooperation/deception scenarios. Cooperation tasks are listed as acceptable examples for the Perception and Understanding of Self construct, and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast.

This is a within-group, whole-brain task contrast (COOP>DEC) in healthy adult participants probing theory-of-mind/social cognition (cooperation vs deception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, resting-state, or between-group analysis, and thus meets the social_processing_all inclusion criteria.

The contrast COOP>DEC comes from a group-level, whole-brain task fMRI study of healthy volunteers (as stated in the abstract) and directly contrasts cooperative (positive social/affiliative) interactions with deceptive interactions. This is a task measuring cooperation (an example domain listed under Affiliation/Attachment) and is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a within-group, voxelwise task contrast (COOP>DEC) in healthy adult participants from a ToM task that directly probes cooperation vs deception — a Social Communication domain (cooperation). The report uses whole-brain thresholds (height and extent), is not ROI/ connectivity or between-group, so it meets the inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, voxelwise within-subject contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy adult volunteers performing a theory-of-mind/social task (cooperation vs. cooperation/deception). It is task-evoked whole-brain univariate activation (not ROI, connectivity, or a between-group comparison) and therefore meets the inclusion criteria for social_processing_all.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOP>DEC) from healthy adult participants using a theory-of-mind task that explicitly probes understanding others' intentions/expectations (cooperation vs deception). It is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group analysis and fits the Perception and Understanding of Others construct.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOP>DEC) in a healthy adult sample using a social interaction (cooperation vs deception) ToM task. ‘Cooperation’ paradigms are listed as examples for the Perception and Understanding of Self construct (e.g., cooperation/competition/social comparison). Although the task probes mental states in social interaction (ToM), the cooperation condition fits the annotation's inclusion examples and the analysis meets the sample and whole-brain criteria.

This is a within-group, whole-brain univariate task contrast on healthy adult participants (n=13) comparing cooperation vs cooperation/deception. The analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrast, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate contrast (COOP>COOPDEC) from healthy adult participants in a theory-of-mind task comparing cooperative vs cooperation/deception conditions. The task probes understanding of others' intentions/expectations (Perception and Understanding of Others — Understanding Mental States), and the analysis is not an ROI, connectivity, or between-group comparison.

The task probes cooperation (an affiliation-related process) and this is a within-group, voxelwise contrast (not ROI or connectivity), so it meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject univariate contrast (main effect of viewing eyes) in healthy adult participants performing a social task (viewing others' eyes and pupillary dynamics). Although the contrast is a whole-brain, group-level map on healthy adults (meeting several methodological inclusion criteria), the task contrasts reflect theory-of-mind reasoning about other characters' intentions (cooperation vs cooperation/deception). The construct 'perception_self' requires processes related to awareness, monitoring or judgments about the self (e.g., self-knowledge, agency, social comparison/cooperation framed as self-related). This contrast targets others' mental states rather than self-related processing, so it should be excluded.

Although this is a healthy-group, whole-brain task-evoked analysis, the task probes pupillary exchange and social salience (viewing eyes and dynamic pupil coherence/discordance), not measures of affiliation or attachment (e.g., kinship, close relationships, loved one vs stranger, cooperation). Therefore it does not meet the task/content requirement for the 'affiliation_attachment' category.

This is an ROI analysis (title: "Region of interest analysis") rather than a group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrast, so it fails the "Whole-brain evidence" inclusion criterion. The analysis is described as a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis. Although the task is social (viewing eyes/pupillary exchange) in healthy adults, the inclusion criteria require a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrast; ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

The analysis is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (table/study label: "Region of interest analysis") rather than a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise map. This is a region-of-interest analysis (table/study labeled 'Region of interest analysis'), not a group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map. The exclusion criteria disallow ROI analyses, so it cannot be included despite the task involving perception of others' eye cues.

This is a region-of-interest (ROI) analysis (analysis name: "Region of interest analysis"), which violates the inclusion requirement for a group-level, whole-brain univariate voxelwise map. ROI analyses are explicitly excluded.

Although the contrast is pink noise versus high-distress cry, it still indexes neural responses to infant stimuli within a whole-brain within-group comparison and therefore meets the affiliation/attachment inclusion criteria.

This is a group-level, within-subject whole-brain contrast (pink noise vs high-distress infant cry) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) using an auditory infant-cry task. Infant cries are social, non-facial communicative signals (reception of non-facial communication), so the contrast measures social communication and meets the inclusion (and does not meet the exclusion) criteria.

This is a group-level, whole-brain univariate task contrast in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women) from an experiment that probes perception of infant cries (others' emotional states). This is a group-level whole-brain univariate contrast (low- vs high-distress infant cries) in healthy adult participants (nulliparous women).
